TheAndSys (2024-07-06T06:50:33.674Z): Subtle difference with *sho* that just so happened to matter to me
TheAndSys (2024-07-06T06:54:23.226Z): Specifically, at least given my understanding of **sho** as per the FAQ, **sho** implies you weren't satisfying the property before, and you've undergone a change that makes you now satisfy it. aıchı +2 `en` @Machy #u0qfp0BlO 2022-02-05T21:02:07.990Z
▯ alieves that ▯ is the case.
Machy (2022-02-05T21:02:27.676Z): an alief is an idea that, while not considered to be true, nonetheless garners a strong emotional reaction. Like jumping at shadows after watching a horror movie: you believe there's nothing to be scared of, but you're scared anyway. The notion that there's a monster in those shadows is an example of an alief.
Machy (2022-02-05T21:04:00.847Z): Best thing about conlanging is getting to make words for incredibly obscure concepts before filling obvious gaps like "fishing".
lassc (2022-12-04T02:12:33.345Z): +1 for interesting concept and nice word form

aıja +1 `en` @robintown #wq3qEJ2TE 2023-11-09T19:31:38.888Z
▯ gets ▯ to satisfy property ▯.
robintown (2023-11-09T19:36:24.462Z): Etymology: Originally **ja**. **taı** was later added to avoid polysemy, which was further reduced to **aı**.
robintown (2023-11-09T20:14:27.808Z): In colloquial speech, this word still commonly takes the form of 'ja' in serial verbs, but only in the falling tone.
robintown (2023-11-25T18:37:11.883Z): Compared to **tua**, this word has the additional semantic nuance of enticing or helping another agent to enter some state.

aımu +2 `en` @official #tOc9ZGaHv0 2023-01-13T19:24:49.528Z
polarity: ‘NEG.CONTR’; contrastive negation: not in fact (contradicting a salient positive claim)
Ilmen (2025-10-31T09:45:18.969Z): This predicate expresses that its argument is false and that this disagrees with a proposition from the immediately preceding discourse (there should be one most salient proposition). Like the opposite of German "doch" and French "si", but as a verb. If no argument is provided, it defaults to the negation of the most salient proposition.
Ilmen (2025-10-31T09:46:00.556Z): A: Jaq cho hó jí B: Aımu, ꝡä cho hó súq. A: "He really likes me!" B: "No, he doesn't."
Ilmen (2025-10-31T09:46:38.934Z): A: Gı hú fafuaq B: Aımu. A: "That movie is good." B: "No, (it isn't)."

aımu +2 `en` @Hoemai #zJJysQXen 2022-08-06T19:57:04.300Z
▯ is not* the case.
Hoemai (2022-08-06T19:57:13.692Z): This predicate expresses that its argument is false and that this disagrees with a proposition from the immediately preceding discourse (there should be one most salient proposition). Like the opposite of German "doch" and French "si", but as a verb. If no argument is provided, it defaults to the negation of the most salient proposition.
Hoemai (2022-08-06T19:57:32.124Z): A: **Jảq chỏ hó jí** B: **Aımu chô hó súq**. A: "He really likes me!" B: "No, he doesn't."

aımuru ± `en` @uakci #lZ77iFT1j 2022-11-19T17:20:56.976Z
connective: indeed not X, and Y
uakci (2022-11-19T17:21:33.323Z): similar to **buru** except that it "adds in" a **bu** if one isn't already present in the left connectand
uakci (2022-11-19T17:22:31.997Z): so, both **bủ nủı aımuru sảo** and **nủı aımuru sảo** are meant to be correct and two different ways of phrasing the same thing (the former requiring less forethought), whereas **bủ nủı buru sảo** would mean the wrong thing (due to double negation)
uakci (2022-11-19T17:22:46.743Z): < **aımu** + **ru**, in analogy with **buru** < **bu** + **ru**

interjection: early termination of sentence
lassc (2025-03-18T12:07:02.752Z): clarification: this is used as a way of essentially going "no, i shant" as you're saying something. i can imagine this being used in a variety of ways, like a playful way of getting the other person to "fill the blank" for what you were about to say, genuinely just stopping yourself before you say something embarassing, etc etc
lassc (2025-03-18T13:30:28.505Z): cf. **sıanha**, which is very similar but avoids the connotation of discouragement of seeking further information and the connotation of negation of what was previously said
lassc (2025-03-18T14:05:51.034Z): ex. «Tú ë tıjuı úmo chéq nä jaq jaı jí... Ma chı súq ꝡá... ame, ame, hahaha!»

áqna +1 `en` @robintown #cY-zD26_p 2025-08-21T23:15:41.710Z
pronoun: ‘REFL.ND’; non-distributive reflexive pronoun
robintown (2025-08-21T23:37:21.655Z): Subtly different in meaning to **áq**: "He kıaı hú poq áq" means "Those people (each) care for their own self (singular)", while "He kıaı hú poq áqna" means "Those people (taken as a group) care for themselves (the whole group)".
robintown (2025-08-21T23:43:15.507Z): This word exists to fill out Kuna's theory of reflexives and subject-sharing, mostly. I don't quite know if this is aligned with how Hoemai imagines **áq** to work.
robintown (2025-08-21T23:44:44.712Z): (But I do think it fits pretty snugly into the grammar)

ara ± `en` @fagri #x7zcTa-RL 2021-10-04T15:24:21.663Z
Conjunction: incomplete 'or' group
fagri (2021-10-04T15:25:06.262Z): etymology: more or less a priori, but could be a short form of "muara" and is also reminiscent of "maru" which itself is a shortened form of "muaru"
fagri (2021-10-04T15:27:03.921Z): Note copied over from "maru": requires that conjunctions be thought of as N-ary operations under the hood, so that "baq pıca ara baq nacho ara baq takou" is (easily) interpreted to mean "pizza or nachos or tacos or something" rather than whatever you get if you link it up as two binary linkages

áꝡa +3 `en` @uakci #G7fiMCu2v 2023-11-05T17:56:24.368Z
pronoun: referring to the 1st, 2nd, or 3rd “person” when the individual in question does not want to have **jí**/**súq**/**nháo** used to refer to them
uakci (2023-11-05T17:57:15.643Z): sometimes seen as ‘this one’ in english, or as consistent use of a 3rd “person” pronoun or a name instead of the «appropriate» personal pronoun
uakci (2023-11-05T17:58:52.514Z): in a conversation between an **áꝡa** user and a non-**áꝡa** user, the former would use **áꝡa** to refer to themselves and **súq** to the listener, but the latter would use **áꝡa** for the listener. when both entities involved are **áꝡa** users then the referent is ambiguous but let me assure you they’re gonna enjoy it that way too

ba- +1 `en` @fagri #d7CKAbw2C 2023-01-06T03:32:15.143Z
Prefix: lexicalizing modifier. Creates a new multi-word opaque vocabulary item out of the word this prefix attaches to and the word before it, with the semantic suggestion that the relationship between the two parts is similar to that invoked by the «be-» prefix
fagri (2023-01-06T03:36:50.423Z): Example: The term «budo ba-hıao» ("noodle of harm") could be defined as an informal synonym for "snake"
fagri (2023-01-06T03:41:52.797Z): Another example: the terms "malum prohibitum" and "malum in se" could be calqued into Toaq as «huı ba-juao» and «huı ba-huı»
fagri (2023-01-06T03:45:42.991Z): The relationship can also be the one invoked by the «ce-» prefix
fagri (2023-01-06T07:01:53.110Z): «Laı ba-teoq» "Question mark"
fagri (2023-01-22T01:35:02.100Z): Can also be used for multi-part names
uakci (2023-05-22T07:37:46.889Z): also see my redefinition #IHbG6HTs_

báq ± `en` @official #K-c1LvgqDTB 2023-01-13T19:24:49.745Z
determiner: ‘GEN’; generic; X-kind

báq ± `en` @robintown #F-7uwwkD5 2024-07-09T14:17:45.924Z
determiner: ‘GEN’; generic; an X / Xs / “the X”
robintown (2024-07-09T14:20:51.575Z): The sense of "the X" shown here is that of sentences like "The tiger is a fierce predator".
robintown (2025-03-01T16:46:00.628Z): This determiner is also appropriate for referring to mass nouns that would be used as bare singulars in English: "Gold is a metal" → "He loha báq eloa"

beqheq ± `en` @Laqme #vaw750f7d 2019-04-23T10:43:26.000Z
▯ is the convex hull of ▯.
Laqme (2019-04-23T10:49:36.000Z): For example, if the mú bẻqhēq is a plural constant referring to some fence posts in a circular arrangement, then the béqhēq is the space (set of points) they enclose. In general, the góanē of a béqhēq quantifies the "amount of space across which the mú bẻqhēq are spread out", so this offers a precise way to define concepts like "density" or "spreading out".

robintown (2023-01-06T02:22:45.204Z): Actually no, use **dîam** for "enough for ▯ to be the case"

bıaq +2 `en` @fagri #iiuwaW7Vc 2021-07-27T04:46:16.438Z

bıaq ± `en` @uakci #7U2raYU2D 2021-09-09T22:10:59.135Z
▯ is enough the case for ▯ to be the case; ▯ satisfies property ▯ to enough an extent to satisfy property ▯.
uakci (2021-09-09T22:11:56.731Z): parallels **duı**. always assumes the ternary form in serials, where it subordinates at the second slot (e.g., **bıaq mỉa dủa** = x₁ knows enough to have pty x₂)
uakci (2021-09-09T22:14:18.108Z): this word can also be understood as the fusion of @fagri’s two alternatives to the official **bıaq** (#OmubwuaVxD) – cf. #iiuwaW7Vc, #nE5zNnIYx

boq ± `en` @el #9NrxNpPfT 2023-01-06T02:17:51.894Z
▯ (evt) happening prevents ▯ (prop) from being the case
el (2023-01-06T02:18:30.250Z): event-enabled version of the official defn to allow for use as a delta adverbial
el (2023-01-06T02:28:34.454Z): kw: stops, precludes
Ilmen (2025-10-30T22:04:21.557Z): I don't think ⟪boq⟫ is different from ⟪ca⟫, which IMO should also take abstract arguments: when you say ⟪eating this causes illness⟫, ⟪illness⟫ is abstract, you are not compelled to pick an ultraspecific individual result.

boq ± `toa` @el #ifaizOniX 2023-01-06T02:25:42.786Z

boq ± `pl` @jiqci #xirISq-4dx 2023-07-31T08:19:52.665Z
To, że ▯ zachodzi, zapobiega/uniemożliwia zajście ▯.

boq ± `en` @Isi #oPKFOa9-4 2024-09-08T12:35:12.910Z
predicate: ‘prevent’; ▯ prevents ▯ from happening.
Isi (2024-09-08T13:08:31.982Z): The first slot is a thing and the second is an event.
Isi (2024-09-08T13:08:37.805Z): The idea behind these slots being this way: (1) I feel that there's not a big difference between a proposition or event preventing something from happening vs. a thing preventing it from happening. (2) It's possible to prevent a single event from happening but not preventing a different event from making the proposition true; e.g. you could prevent someone's death (by curing their disease), but then they die anyways (for unrelated reasons).
Isi (2024-09-08T13:08:43.452Z): Though I'm not sure if the semantics make sense when you refer to an event that doesn't actually happen.

scientific notation incorporating verb: turns following numbers X and Y into verb: ▯ is X * 10^Y.
Machy (2022-10-17T16:38:27.084Z): Scientific notation
Machy (2022-10-17T16:38:46.885Z): Usage example: "Cỉeq shí héi ní da" = "This is one times ten to the tenth power." Both shí and héi are incorporated into the verb, meaning you can use "cíeq shí héi" to mean "one times ten to the tenth power."

⚠ cnopıt ± `en` @jiqci #HqMAk53Uj 2025-01-13T10:32:31.410Z
interjection: xnopyt

co- ± `en` @Ilmen #g6y1a3Xzs 2023-05-23T21:02:20.861Z
prefix: to display, noticeably do X with the hope that it is perceived by…

co ± `en` @uakci #JFj7Z2C7b 2022-08-21T20:33:33.304Z
cataphoric predicate: ▯ is something that satisfies a floating relative clause headed by **nheı**.
uakci (2022-08-21T20:34:30.427Z): à la **nu** except that a **nheı** clause that follows specifies the semantic content of the **co**
uakci (2022-08-21T20:35:55.387Z): **fả sa cỏ kủne jí, nheı rỉq hó da** ‘such a dog came up to me that it was green’
uakci (2022-08-21T20:36:39.376Z): there are no restrictions on how to use **co** tone-wise; **có**, **cô**, even **cõ** seem all like fine options (maybe not **cò** though lol)
uakci (2022-08-21T20:42:30.167Z): creative inversion example: **hẻ cỏ baq nhỏykuq nheı bủ kỉu chẻaqjıe hó** ‘such are liars that they can’t possibly be trusted’
uakci (2022-08-21T20:46:47.220Z): **cõ bı gỉaqduy nháo nheı cả hóa kîeq jí** ‘they dance such that it [= their dancing] causes me to be disgusted’ (≈ **gỉaqduy nháo lũ cả hóa kîeq jí**)
uakci (2022-08-21T20:48:32.347Z): **tỉ có baq sỏaq nheı jẻı sôı há chéq** ‘it was in a park, one’s fighting with each other’
uakci (2022-08-21T20:50:37.994Z): thinking of allowing **nheı** to associate with DPs/CPs too (imagine removing the **jẻı** from this last example)

co ± `en` @robintown #SAluQIctB 2022-12-10T05:31:19.645Z
number component: decimal point

co -1 `toa` @Ilmen #bQyn-xcCm 2020-01-31T11:39:34.001Z
co hao = meq lu hıa hóa lî hao na na.

co -1 `en` @Laqme #Z0AzFwtqc 2022-11-14T10:20:23.007Z
determiner: 'how many?'
Laqme (2022-11-14T10:21:50.751Z): This word was removed from the official dictionary; nowadays you should ask questions using **tıopuı** instead.
Ilmen (2025-10-30T22:12:01.243Z): This should have the form ⟪có⟫, not ⟪co⟫.

có +2 `en` @uakci #Rs8NuzD9J 2023-05-30T08:08:47.171Z
pronoun: cataphoric; a placeholder that anticipates an extra noun phrase after the clause
fagri (2023-05-30T08:10:24.854Z): Example usage: «Ca có wä jaı jı́, wä gaı jı́ sá shuao de gu»
uakci (2023-05-30T08:12:00.126Z): akin to **nä** (and as such termable as a cleft) except the extracted noun phrase appears after the clause, not before. we assume that this NP appears after all adverbials (i.e., a full clause, right below CP) and participates in a cleft structure that’s exactly like **nä** but not pronounced (we’re able to pull this off because we don’t need to disambiguate the end of a noun phrase from the start of a predicate)
uakci (2023-05-30T08:15:12.930Z): in other words, if a **nä**-cleft looks like [vP (fronted subject) [v' [v nä] [CPrel with hóa]], then a **có**-cleft shall look like [vP [v' [CPrel with có] [v ∅]] (fronted subject)]

có ± `en` @robintown #sCGWzZtkJ 2024-09-09T22:17:32.638Z
pronoun: ‘it.SUB’; correlative pronoun for subordinate clauses
robintown (2024-09-09T22:17:52.637Z): https://toaq.me/Clause_Reform

chatua -1 `en` @Machy #M1gUCqqzk 2021-10-01T18:48:53.737Z
▯ is a word that, while not actually a grammar word, has the function of helping other words rather than providing content of its own.
Machy (2021-10-01T18:49:51.059Z): Many of these would be grammar words in other languages but are just predicates in Toaq.
Machy (2021-10-01T18:50:50.292Z): This refers to all non-particle words that work to coordinate other words, like zuaq, mu, kuı......
Machy (2021-10-09T18:43:53.254Z): "coordinator word"
Machy (2021-10-09T18:47:28.134Z): TAM words and semantic roles are also chatua
Machy (2021-10-09T18:48:13.249Z): "empty predicate" - xorxes

chém +1 `en` @uakci #zz7P--gDb 2023-07-23T10:06:57.959Z
focus marker: and vice versa; marks one of 2+ constructs in a sentence to be permuted, or (as a shorthand) the sole nominal construct to be permuted with the grammatical subject
uakci (2023-08-30T20:12:15.364Z): the description is a little complicated, so, example: **cho chém jí chém súq** = **cho jí chém súq** = **cho jí súq rú cho súq jí**
uakci (2023-08-30T20:12:35.895Z): (1) can be shortened into (2) if there are only two **chém**s; otherwise, there would be ambiguity
uakci (2023-08-30T20:13:26.613Z): (and yes the example happens to be identical to just **cho úmo chéq**)

uakci (2019-03-16T01:14:44.000Z): this word desperately needs a root. perhaps not in this exact shape or form, but… distill your donkeys, guys!

uakci (2019-03-16T01:25:23.000Z): +1, pff
uakci (2019-03-16T01:52:57.000Z): result of discussions on 2019-03-15/16 and 2018-09-03 about this word and the phrase ‘being worth it’ respectively: choaikēo/2 states that 1) B happens if A happens and 2) both A and B happening is better [for the speaker] than neither happening.

▯ adheres to the tenets of ▯-ism; ▯ is ▯-istic.
uakci (2022-04-15T17:25:21.540Z): = **chuaqraq** but shorter and sweeter in compounds
uakci (2022-04-15T17:26:19.850Z): e.g., **ludychu'aq** ‘Luddite (person, practice)’; **nueqcıachu'aq** ‘vegetarian (person, diet)’
uakci (2022-04-15T17:28:52.838Z): also excellent as an adverb: **pủ dủq pỏaq nháo baq fủqsaıchuo lũdychu'aq da** ‘they would tear down looms in a Luddite fashion’
uakci (2022-04-15T17:32:27.795Z): another example: **hẻ nủeqcıachu'aq chûq jí** = **hẻ chûq jí nũeqcıachu'aq** = **hẻ chûq jí chà núeqcıachuaq** ‘I eat vegetarianism…ically (in a vegetarian fashion / in adherence with vegetarianism)’

evie (2025-09-06T23:30:37.459Z): toaq's orthography is phonemic so this is /ˈtɕûŋ.ʔù.àj/
Lisaki (2025-09-06T23:37:41.547Z): I added it because speakers would likely pronounce it intentionally cutesy. chuqꝡaı could be an alternate spelling :3

chusıbo ± `en` @uakci #4QoriqO6n 2023-11-03T07:28:33.460Z
▯ is the average of ▯ (plural).
uakci (2023-11-03T07:30:03.371Z): the idea is that this could extend to propositions: **chúsıbo, ꝡâ toı nháo súq** ‘their average treatment of you’, not really referring to any one event all in all but more to an abstract embodiment (cf. **sıbo**) of an average that could then be quantified with **ne** or talked about generically in other ways
uakci (2023-11-03T07:32:56.783Z): in other words, these two sentences are meant to be congruent: **ꝡé he cha hôa báq, ë toı nháo hó** ‘that which, as a rule, is the manner of their treatment of you’ and **ꝡé cha hôa chúsıbo, ꝡâ toı nháo súq** ‘the way they treat you on average’

de- +1 `en` @Laqme #gAPROnUS8 2024-09-19T13:46:39.491Z
prefix for "adverbial auxiliaries" (verb → verb-ily do...)
Laqme (2024-09-19T13:49:20.085Z): For example, **Dẹjaı jí, lä …** means "I happily …", and **dẹjaı marao** means "happily dance".
Laqme (2024-09-19T13:49:48.037Z): This is useful for sneaking adverbs into serials: **shao dẹjuaı leo noaq** means "want to earnestly try to read"
Laqme (2024-09-19T13:54:04.475Z): Only works on intransitive verbs, but you can first turn transitive verbs intransitive with other prefixes: **shao denịbıe sea jí** = "I want to hereafter rest"

déom ± `en` @seaqtaq #lacrX6OJx 2024-08-06T01:29:18.732Z
focus prefix: possibly X/perhaps X
seaqtaq (2024-08-06T01:29:30.310Z): This is like daı as a focus prefix. Thus it has more permissive syntax. In simple cases, there appears to be no benefit, e.g. "Daı chuq náq zéo" ≈ "Chuq déom náq sá zeo". But in more complex ones, e.g. "Chuq líq rú déom náq", I believe the benefit is apparent in the rephrasing required with daı
seaqtaq (2024-08-06T01:33:44.672Z): Haola déom X Y == Daı haola kú X Y
seaqtaq (2024-08-06T01:37:38.408Z): Ergo "Chuq líq rú déom náq sá zéo" == "Chuq líq sá zeo rú daı chuq kú náq sá zeo"

deoq +3 `en` @robintown #GtJOyIdx8 2023-01-15T04:07:44.108Z
▯ tells / communicates to ▯ that ▯ is the case.
robintown (2023-01-15T04:10:12.256Z): I find the property version of **deoq** difficult to use in practice, and **duatua** to be a misnomer, so I propose this
Ilmen (2025-10-31T19:11:51.408Z): On the one hand, words like ⟪kuq⟫ nowadays no longer have an addressee slot. But on the other hand, removing it with ⟪deoq⟫ would result in pretty much the same thing as either ⟪kuaq⟫ or ⟪ruaq⟫ I guess, unless we adopt my idea of ⟪▯ performs speech act ▯⟫, which is unspecific with respect to the nature of the speech act…

deoqzaosu ± `en` @seaqtaq #rt2AkRPuN 2023-03-08T11:02:16.267Z
▯ is one's communicative identifier/signature; ▯ is one's "voice" (not necessarily vocal)
seaqtaq (2023-03-08T11:08:04.144Z): This is an abstraction of english's "voice" across every possible communicative medium, be it sound waves, the electromagnetic spectrum, tactile, olfactory, etc. Intended to be less anthropocentric, as the existence of this word means that it is not necessary to use the metaphor of "voice" to attempt to refer to communicative signatures in general. In addition to being less anthropocentric, it can be used for humans that can't speak as well. The word could be used to refer to the visual pecularities and idiosyncracies of the way one signs a particular sign language as well

du- ± `en` @uakci #M790m0waZ 2024-02-12T18:04:08.813Z
prefix: marks the following material as putative – not asserted as true and not part of the point one is making
uakci (2024-02-12T18:06:09.202Z): like **du** but not quite. firstly, this can attach to any material – i imagine **dụ́sa** could be licit. secondly, while **du X** makes a *positive* claim about something seeming to be X,**dụ-X** makes no positive or negative claim – it strips assertive force from X

duaı +2 `en` @robintown #BqjCzzUst 2021-08-01T05:41:41.400Z
▯ must be the case; ▯ must be the case if ▯ is the case.
robintown (2021-08-01T05:45:11.103Z): This is the more regular form for modals.
Laqme (2021-10-23T16:46:03.660Z): this expresses an obligation
Laqme (2021-12-02T22:30:01.876Z): “deontic obligation”
Laqme (2023-07-18T13:06:11.490Z): required
Ilmen (2025-10-12T19:52:04.339Z): Why not a different word than the official ⟪duaı⟫? I interpret the original as having a focus on the person who is *reponsible* for the duty/obligation, and this new meaning doesn't allow expressing responsability.
Ilmen (2025-10-12T19:54:08.395Z): Admittedly, the wording of the original definition is ambiguous and can also be interpreted as allowing ⟪the door ⟦duaı⟧/must be opened⟫ which is not about responsability. But I suspect this isn't what the original meaning is about, at least if we take into account the verb's frame.
Ilmen (2025-10-12T19:55:40.572Z): I guess if this new definition were to be adopted, ⟪duaıgıla⟫ could work as a replacement for the previous meaning, but it's a bit longish…

duı ± `en` @robintown #ZzCuiCA1o 2021-09-18T17:56:50.337Z
▯ satisfies property ▯ too much.

Laqme (2023-02-18T00:47:00.397Z): So, **êaq rao púchaq** means the same thing as **râo púchaq** but it can only occur in the main clause. This can be used to trigger self-termination of an object subclause and place main clause adverbials after it! But it's totally not a terminator I promise!!

eq- +1 `en` @evie #NdFtFx4Pv 2024-06-25T19:15:38.546Z

eq +3 `en` @robintown #RaqwykTBg 2023-01-18T20:28:15.462Z
▯ is/are ▯.
robintown (2023-01-18T20:28:18.450Z): A generic copula. Often used with kinds, as in "Eq ní báq kato, ꝡë lụıkuaq shao sía poq, ꝡä bo hó hóa", but can also be used without kinds, as in "Bu eq jí póq, ꝡë joaı súna hóa nha". Aside from not being an object incorporating verb, eq differs from **jeı** only in how it interacts with kinds.
kazoo (2025-01-12T18:44:01.750Z): example of how this differs from *jeı*: if you say "a pencil is green" with jeı, it'd imply "green is a pencil" is also correct. With eq, you're taking the safe option and you avoid this problem.

eq ± `en` @uakci #xZMm80OIG 2022-08-14T20:31:05.797Z
▯ is an instance/manifestation/reification of kind ▯.
uakci (2022-08-14T20:31:44.382Z): ≈ **guo**. stems from discussions about a separate tone for **baq** and SOV reshuffling

etu +2 `en` @uakci #J_cnp9RZG 2022-07-10T14:04:54.186Z
determiner: **tu** but bubbles up to illocution-phrase level
uakci (2022-07-10T14:05:35.423Z): **shı** equivalent would be **etushı**. based on **eru**; this determiner could be understood as "boiling down" to a (however long) coordination phrase involving **eru**
uakci (2022-07-10T14:06:04.436Z): **hỉa etushı mẻa súq moq** 'how are each of you doing?'
uakci (2022-07-10T14:07:11.451Z): spitballing-wise we could have **ésuq** for **etushı mẻa súq** and maybe this particle would never really get much use beyond that. who knows. no commitment intended!

étu ± `en` @Laqme #ltpsbGJOp 2022-12-24T13:32:35.023Z
determiner: "each X" (making a new speech act for each X)
Laqme (2022-12-24T13:40:00.303Z): For example, **Zudeq étu Toaqpoq hí móq?** asks "what languages does Lina speak? what languages does uakci speak? what...", rather than asking about common languages spoken by **tú** Toaqpoq.

foa +1 `en` @official #7Ye6BLVHQL 2019-05-05T22:25:31.378Z
predicate: ‘feel’; ▯ feels ▯ (good or bad); ▯ is ▯ (ill or well).
Laqme (2021-08-31T11:01:57.400Z): "fare" as in "(to) fare well" (or "farti" as in "kiel vi fartas?")
uakci (2022-07-25T10:32:58.105Z): ▯’s life/day/overall disposition is proceeding in a manner describable by property ▯
Ilmen (2024-12-27T11:18:39.738Z): It may be better for the object to be a quale rather than a property.

foa ± `en` @uakci #XJQsv4_Lf 2023-01-03T10:53:11.491Z
▯ feels / is doing/faring in a way exemplified with property ▯; ▯ satisfies property ▯, and this is reflective of their mood/disposition/state of mind/status in life/how they’re doing; ▯ is up to satisfying property ▯.
uakci (2023-01-03T10:54:21.582Z): a much more useful redefinition of **foa** that doesn't artificially separate the mood-haver x1 from the mood property x2. if you're having trouble understanding this definition: it's like **ıq** but it says that this property is a mood or state that you're going through
uakci (2023-01-03T10:56:02.413Z): notably, **foa gı** and **foa huı** now mean something else (sth like ‘being (morally?) good is my mood’) and you'll have to use **gıfoa**, **huıfoa** instead. but also it lets you say **foa nuokuaı** 'be in a state of mind of feeling sleepy', **foa doekaı** 'be down for some programming / be in the mood/zone for programming', etc.
uakci (2023-03-12T09:29:42.605Z): some notes about the notes: (1) **foa bâq gı** also works; (2) since this **foa** is a hyponym of **ıq**, this implies that one who **foa doekaı**s is already one who **doekaı**s. you can say **foa taoshao sạdoekaı** for ‘feel like you’re down for some programming’, whose compositionality i like. i suppose that in this sense **foa** is just like **taq moe ıq**

⚠ g ± `en` @Laqme #bvr8NpVm6 2025-03-30T22:59:46.416Z
clitic: make the next word not attach to incorporated/predicatizer objects
Laqme (2025-03-30T23:01:30.122Z): This is a sort of revival of Gamma's **ga** terminator. It's pronounced /gə/ with a very short neutral-tone vowel.
Laqme (2025-03-30T23:05:33.237Z): After a phrase like **sá paı kê naq**, you can use **g duagı** to adjectivally modify "paı", or **g ꝡë** to attach a relative clause to "paı", or **g róı** to conjoin that whole DP with another DP.
Laqme (2025-03-30T23:08:52.191Z): **sá kue po báq foto de g sao** "a big book of beautiful photos"
Laqme (2025-03-30T23:11:10.614Z): I gave this experimental word an experimental form because I feel bad taking CVs, but I'd be just as happy with this as **ga**.

ga- ± `en` @uakci #ZV2R-s68D 2023-11-01T22:20:24.360Z
prefix: combines previous word X and next (attached) word Y into the compound YX, expressed as two parts for clarity or when forming an ad-hoc compound
uakci (2023-11-01T22:21:37.847Z): note that not all compounds can use **gạ-** – only those which the speaker deems are a compound of two other existing lexical items can. so **marao** cannot be **rao gạkma** (unless the speaker really thinks that’s the etymology of **marao**. i don’t judge)
uakci (2023-11-01T22:22:23.071Z): **rao gạma** (misspelling)
uakci (2023-11-01T22:42:05.431Z): one other thing this prefix is nice for (apart from ad-hoc-ing compounds and decomposing existing compounds for the benefit of the listener) is breaking down an enormous word into two tone contours

⚠ ga -1 `en` @oldofficial #GK2pzkfRE 2022-08-01T23:55:25.178Z
terminator: ‘[end]’; end object incorporating verb or name verb

gâ ± `en` @Hoemai #a2boFbpIg 2025-03-07T14:42:21.270Z
pendent particle: allows placing an argument in front and outside of a phrase in order to bind a variable within that phrase
Hoemai (2025-03-07T14:42:37.268Z): Originally I thought that this would just be an empty preposition and therefore precede its complement. But this would require a change to the rules governing adjunct placement and scope, because pendent constructions often appear between subject and object (see examples below), and it would also limit its application.
Hoemai (2025-03-07T14:42:45.454Z): I also seem to prefer the feel of **gâ** as a postposition. Given these points, I propose that **gâ** be like a barnacle.
Hoemai (2025-03-07T14:42:51.655Z): Like a barnacle, it sits on top of whatever (phrase) is right next to it; its host is actually its complement, and the pendent argument itself is the specifier.
Hoemai (2025-03-07T14:43:08.671Z): Example usage: **Shoe jí, sía raı gâ, ꝡä kuq súq ráı.** "I allow, for no X, that you say X." **Dua jí, sá poq gâ, ꝡä cho hó súq.** "I know, of someone, that they like you."
Hoemai (2025-03-07T14:43:19.352Z): Based on Eatoaq's **nâ**, but keeps fronting-**nä** and pendent-**gâ** syntactically and phonologically distinct.

gaq- +1 `en` @uakci #JTZI3uEyi 2023-10-16T14:06:32.061Z
prefix: split the subject into two arguments, which are then **róı**d together: ▯ together with ▯ collectively do X.
uakci (2023-10-16T14:07:55.106Z): this is like the use of ‘with’ (or sometimes null) with some plural intransitive verbs in english: “we had a feud” ~ “i had a feud with them”; “we cuddled” ~ “i cuddled [with] them”
fagri (2023-10-16T14:59:14.929Z): +1
fagri (2023-10-16T15:00:55.703Z): This prefix suggests a paradigm where words like «maıgaq» are rephrased from having two slots to having one slot, which is something I've liked the idea of for a while. The current definitions could be recovered with this prefix when they're needed
fagri (2023-10-16T15:01:43.872Z): «Maıgaq ı́me» = «Gạqmaıgaq jı́ nháo»

gaq +3 `en` @robintown #5n4Dw0Jzw 2023-02-05T06:56:11.544Z
▯ accompanies / is together with ▯.
robintown (2023-02-05T06:59:16.906Z): Subject-sharing adverbials allow us to do away with the property place that this word has previously had.

gaqnua ± `en` @uakci #xMVD5AmBZ 2022-09-28T08:44:27.035Z
▯ takes from ▯ property ▯, not depriving them of it; ▯ takes a share of ▯’s property ▯.
uakci (2022-09-28T08:45:30.628Z): this one is tricky to word, but it means ‘to get property Z from Y while allowing Y to retain Z’. **gaqnua** is to **ıqnua** as **gaqdoa** is to **ıqdoa**
uakci (2022-09-28T08:46:38.815Z): **ỉqnua chủq súq jí** ‘you’re taking food out of my mouth / straight away from my plate / from under my nose’ vs. **gảqnua chủq súq jí** ‘you help yourself with [some of] the food i’m having’

gınu ± `en` @uakci #mVB1pcsn4 2021-07-31T15:17:21.479Z
▯ is fortunately/fortuitously/happily/[luckily] so.
uakci (2021-07-31T15:20:15.943Z): intended to be used in 7th tone, just like **shuaınū**, e.g., Shảı rủqshūa gĩnū da ‘Luckily, it stopped raining’. ‘luckily’ is meant here in a narrow sense – not as an indication of good luck / favourable odds, but as a “polarising” comment explaining the speaker’s positive bias towards the event being described
uakci (2021-07-31T15:22:22.651Z): also differs from **juqgī** in that this word is a discursive comment/remark rather than a statement of benefit

gjjh +1 `en` @jiqci #UhlEWT1nh 2024-03-16T17:55:17.735Z
abbreviation of **gö** **jıjıe**/**jeokuq** **jí** **hóa** "in my (honest) opinion / IMO / IMHO"
evie (2024-11-14T04:14:03.896Z): kw: textspeak

go- +2 `en` @uakci #8N9cUaefr 2023-08-12T15:35:54.990Z
prefix: combine two verbs into a verb–object compound where the action denoted by the verb is specialized by the class of object
uakci (2023-08-12T15:38:58.769Z): in other words, **A gọ-B** is a kind of **A** specific to **B**-s. for example, if A = ‘to sit sb’ and B = ‘baby’, then A **gọ-**B would mean babysitting, or the kind of sitting that’s specific to babies
uakci (2023-08-12T15:39:15.998Z): note: the verb retains its original valency
fagri (2023-11-25T17:22:33.446Z): +1
seaqtaq (2024-07-16T22:07:33.375Z): Keyword: Semantic focuser/classifier

gö +2 `en` @official #BzIeeKT-vsr 2023-01-13T19:24:50.905Z
retroactive cleft: ‘RETROCLE’; lift top-level clause, binding hóa in the following matrix clause
idontremembermypassword (2024-12-01T00:07:31.704Z): could anyone give non-jargon examples? I still didn't take notes to translate all this jargon to any other logical jargon, it's a bit annoying to go back to the overrepetitive lessons or the even more jargonful gramamatique or the unexplainative wiki. I know this language is easier than Eberban, but as poor as logical languages are explained, I succeded at understading Eberban by their given explainations, just because they put examples altogether every explanation, so I could at least figure out by try and miss. with this I can't even try. well, at least I guess gö and jü had examples on the lessons and wikis, other particles here on the other hand...
evie (2024-12-01T00:24:39.174Z): **Puagı báq gochıq, gö chı jí hóa da.** "I think cats are enjoyable"
evie (2024-12-01T00:33:39.924Z): more literally "Cats are enjoyable, I think [that]"

gö +1 `en` @Laqme #XXS8Vt-RQ 2022-12-19T22:47:56.623Z
retroactive CP cleft: wraps the preceding sentence in the following CP
Laqme (2022-12-19T22:47:59.874Z): https://toaq.net/refgram/syntax/#retroactive_cp_cleft
Laqme (2022-12-19T22:50:09.435Z): **Kaqgaı súq báq aıpu, gö bu chı jí hóa.** = [that] You saw a ghost, I don't believe (that).

gö ± `en` @robintown #l02wTUAmv 2024-07-31T01:44:52.347Z
cleft verb: opens incidental clause commenting on the complement of the speech act
robintown (2024-07-31T01:46:01.939Z): Binds the complement of the sentence's speech act to hóa.
robintown (2024-07-31T01:51:04.873Z): De báq rua, gö dua tú poq hóa. "Flowers are beautiful, as everyone knows."
robintown (2024-07-31T01:52:29.944Z): Hoaı mıe nháo, gö chı jí hóa. "He's still alive—I think."
robintown (2024-07-31T01:58:52.921Z): Might even have free placement similar to vocatives: Jaq suao, gö jıe jí hóa, lä sẹuleo já hú. "It's very important, I find, to at least try it."

gô ± `en` @uakci #pE8VKyJ0s 2025-01-03T09:02:28.417Z

gohı ± `en` @Ilmen #d8jpU-R0R 2022-10-07T11:37:32.817Z
The proposition "what satisfies the predicate ▯" is such that ▯ is in relation ▯ with that proposition. More precisely: considering the predicate ▯, the thing ▯ and the relation ▯: for all X, the proposition that X is an argument structure which satisfies the predicate is true iff the thing is in that relation with the proposition.
Ilmen (2022-10-07T11:37:50.706Z): Example: «gỏhı dủa jí jîa lủaqtaı ja da» = «dủa jí jîa lủaqtaı hı da».

The proposition "what satisfies the predicate ▯" is such that ▯ is in relation ▯ with that proposition; more precisely: considering the predicate ▯, the thing ▯ and the relation ▯: for all X, the proposition that X is an argument structure which satisfies the predicate is true iff the thing is in that relation with the proposition, and furthermore, the proposition that X is an argument structure which doesn't satisfy the predicate is true iff the thing is in that relation with the proposition.

▯ is a Toaq word originating from a mistake/confusion between two similar roots.
lassc (2025-03-24T18:23:51.884Z): cf. **nuotoa**,**zakaı**; this deserves a wordform because of how easy this is to do for Toaq in particular relative to other languages when learning vocabulary

gúom ± `en` @uakci #vkH9iauhO 2024-12-31T19:12:57.671Z
focus particle: more (of) X; X more/further; X again/still; X anew; another X / X yet another time
uakci (2024-12-31T19:17:15.767Z): **gıshe, ꝡä bạqjoımoı báq cueche gúom báq mıa jıe** ‘politicians should take public opinion into consideration more’ vs. **gıshe, ꝡä bạqjoımoı gúom báq cueche báq mıa jıe**. in both cases, the speaker wishes for the **ꝡä** clause to happen more (further than already), but in the first case they want more/further/new/other public opinion to be considered and in the second case they want a wider range of politicians (so, including more/further/new/different politicians than already do) to consider public opinion
uakci (2024-12-31T19:17:39.858Z): you can also probably save yourself the nuance and slap **guom** at the start of the clause: **gıshe, ꝡä guom joımoı** etc. etc.

⚠ he -1 `en` @oldofficial #lCjteqqPS5 2022-08-01T23:55:25.736Z

hê ± `en` @Laqme #T89rH7hLr 2023-07-17T01:17:03.065Z
gnomic conditional: **hê, ꝡä X, nä Y** = "As a rule, whenever X is the case, Y is the case."
Laqme (2023-07-17T01:17:43.970Z): (Hoemaı, January 16, 2023) “he is not really an aspect, but I couldn't be arsed to figure out where to put it in the refgram so I left it where it used to be. It belongs to the Modal/AdverbOfQuantification group of words, which have two places (restriction & scope).”
Laqme (2023-07-17T01:18:00.333Z): source: https://discord.com/channels/311223912044167168/889589074011230230/1064656781848092693
Laqme (2023-07-17T01:20:26.481Z): Not really lexical tone — if you see "hê", that means the speaker is using **he** as a modal like **daı** or **ao**, rather than an aspect like **chum** or **luı**.

heomaı ± `en` @fagri #6xy9DLG51 2019-06-30T07:47:59.749Z
▯ is straight (attracted to people of the opposite sex)
fagri (2021-08-02T05:58:58.963Z): (includes bisexual people I think)
maigoi (2024-09-17T10:15:47.518Z): that tells me 'loves what is different', could as well be a xenophile or someone who likes to explore new, different things than they already know
maigoi (2024-09-18T06:13:17.778Z): there should be a shorter root for ( ) is 'romantically' & 'sexually' 'attracted' to ( ) for use instead of mai
mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18T06:25:32.167Z): Hi!  I personally think this word is fine as is because the word “gay” for example, could mean that someone is homoromantic or homosexual.  There can also exist less specific words.  Of course, more specific words are always welcome, but I think most people would rather say “I am straight” than “I am heteroromantic and heterosexual.”
mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18T06:30:18.250Z): As for your note that this word doesn’t mention gender anywhere, the alternative would be heojeqda[mai/romantic-attract/sexual-attract]. You could think of this word as an shortening of that word. Additionally, Toaq compounds are not always just their parts combined. For example, choıshoaı means hawk, but it is a compound word “sharp-wing”
mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18T06:31:25.218Z): Oh, and @maigoi, the word **heoseaq** exists for heterosexual.
mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18T06:34:50.334Z): Additionally, you are free to coin new words as you like.  Most words in Toaq are created by the community based on need.  For example, this word was coined by @fagri, not Hoemai (the creator of Toaq).  So you are more than welcome to create a word for heteromantic :)
mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18T07:02:51.624Z): You can join us on our Discord server https://discord.gg/Wxn6XF4G to discuss coining words.
maigoi (2024-09-22T14:33:53.273Z): hello! I like non-specifity! I just mean the word is indeed nice, but evokes a broader meaning than specifically heterosexuality :)

I think the definition itself could be more... interesting;

now, I don't think there would need to be a compound of three roots, just a new root for the two of them which are very common!

I have no creativity for creating roots and I made a toki pona words generator, not a Toaq one so, I'm unlucky now xD

I like how the community creates its own words, but I'm seeing my way into Toaq for pure aesthetics, and I highly consider grammar (thus learning a logical language) and well-made compounds (so it doesn't make the grammar useless as 'logical'). those factors are important to me, as I wouldn't a logical language being harder to parse than toki pona, due to... autistic reasons ._.

I don't use Discord but suspect this is bridged;

have a nice day!

hıte +2 `en` @robintown #b4xoCB2yQ 2023-12-19T14:05:15.737Z

robintown (2023-12-19T14:05:29.217Z): I'd like this word to be most commonly used in its rising tone form 'íte?' Technically this asks about the listener's own disbelief, but you can imagine this being an idiomatic usage which is ultimately about the speaker's incredulity.

horabaq ± `en` @fagri #R_xY20twN 2019-02-24T17:35:40.000Z
▯ is the hour numbered ▯
fagri (2019-02-24T17:35:58.000Z): Numbers go from 0 to 23. Each hour is a repeating event that takes place for 60 minutes every day.

horachıu ± `en` @fagri #rOEf_3vR2 2019-02-24T17:52:18.000Z
▯ is the time ▯ (three- or four-digit number)
fagri (2019-02-24T17:53:07.000Z): The entity named is the set of evenly spaced points in time that occur at time (h)h:mm
fagri (2019-02-24T17:54:33.000Z): Example: "rào hórāchīu shỉgūgū" = "at 1:22 am", "rào hórāchīu gủhēısāqhēı" = "at 8:30 pm" (= 20:30)
fagri (2019-02-24T17:55:55.000Z): Oh also, a one- or two-digit argument means that only the hour is being named, but it still refers to exactly a set of *points* in time; "rào hórāchīu hẻı" = "at 10:00 am (sharp)"

horachıu ± `en` @Ilmen #9WJsBkgQb 2020-02-06T21:48:41.765Z

húaq ± `en` @uakci #DfEZbQWcV 2024-09-13T15:46:24.486Z
focus particle: the more X, the more …; specifies that it’s X whose extent/intensity contributes to the extent to which the containing clause holds
uakci (2024-09-13T15:47:15.489Z): assumes experimental **sóq** as focus particle (which in that case displaces official **huaq** as **mẹ́asoq** together with **hạ-**)
uakci (2024-09-13T15:47:55.476Z): lynn has already defined **hụaq-** the focus prefix but i think this is both close enough and more pragmatic (for intensification specifically there's also **ꝡạm-**)
uakci (2024-09-13T15:50:00.157Z): **he jaı báq gaqcheo kıhụaqpuı** ≈ loosely ‘the more, the merrier’

fagri (2021-10-05T04:08:00.062Z): When conjunctions are interpreted as N-ary operations, a chain of huji's should produce a list that satisfy the property less and less as the list goes on

ı- ± `en` @TheAndSys #79nP7v3sm 2025-02-18T19:38:08.158Z

ı ± `en` @uakci #1Z1sroujR 2023-01-01T17:25:22.209Z
▯ pertains to cyberspace.
uakci (2023-01-01T17:27:35.518Z): mostly intended as a (formal or informal) prefix for turning meatspace activities into their cyberspace analogues, e.g., **ıtı jí íkua** ‘i’m present/logged into the chatroom’ (also **ịtı jí ̣
uakci (2023-01-01T17:28:46.955Z): although **tı jí íkua** is probably fine too since the literal reading cannot be meant because of the category error
uakci (2023-01-01T17:29:04.385Z): < english e- < electronic
uakci (2023-01-01T17:29:22.220Z): choosing this word form because it gives compounds a highly distinctive sound
uakci (2023-01-01T17:30:30.388Z): the first comment should read “also **ịtı jí ị́kua**”

ıa -1 `en` @el #gdBG3hDWe 2022-11-30T22:38:34.157Z
Some t5-clause involving ▯, satisfies ▯/1

el (2022-11-30T22:38:57.611Z): convenience in serials is also why this is not a PO
el (2022-11-30T22:39:07.094Z): ıa X Y ≈ ıq vêrb ... X ... cy Y, with some (left to context) verb and other arguments

ía +4 `en` @robintown #6WrSpWq97 2024-10-21T22:50:41.427Z
pronoun: null, observative; 'it's X-ing', 'there is X-ing'
robintown (2024-10-21T22:53:09.480Z): By including this particle in the post-field, you can turn any verb into a nullary verb. This is designed for https://toaq.me/Clause_Reform, which does not allow implicit underfilling of verbs.
robintown (2024-10-21T22:55:18.105Z): Examples: "Choa ía" "There is speaking", "Chı jí, ꝡä za patı ía râo ní nuaq" "I think there will be a party tonight"

ïe +3 `en` @Laqme #-ubuUiPzI 2025-01-02T15:07:49.408Z
start editorial parenthetical (closed by **kı**)
Laqme (2025-01-02T15:11:03.887Z): Used inside **mó** … **teo**. This indicates a parenthetical that was not in the actual quote. Inside the parenthetical, **hóa** refers to the quoted text.
Laqme (2025-01-02T15:14:44.081Z): **Kuq nháo mó «Naına Tóeqzu (ïe nu hóa kı) ꝡeı» teo.**  They said, “Toeq [sic] is so cool.”
Laqme (2025-01-02T15:17:28.471Z): And maybe if you use it outside of mó-teo, it lifts the sentence to a quote? **«Jaq jua,» ïe kuq mí Alısı hóa kı, «ní sıo da.»** "This idea," said Alice, "is quite strange."
Ilmen (2025-10-23T11:01:40.921Z): This can presumably also be used for rendering switch to meta descriptions as seen from a third party, as in ⟪They still fail to understand. *facepalm*⟫.

ıga +2 `en` @seaqtaq #PiiTt-Zk- 2024-07-10T21:34:43.987Z

ïgo +1 `en` @seaqtaq #wxeB-9cn1 2024-07-16T08:50:18.604Z
relative retroactive cleft: ‘RELRETROCLE’; lift superordinate clause, binding hóa in the following clause on the same level as said superordinate clause
seaqtaq (2024-07-16T08:51:42.801Z): Intended to cover for a (perceived) weakness of gö—namely that it can only be used to add extra details to the main proposition, and not propositions represented in arbitrarily nested subordinate claues
seaqtaq (2024-07-16T08:53:19.017Z): "Bu chı jí, ꝡá noaq nháo sá, ꝡä fa déo jéarıaq zûo pó báq noaı, ïgo bu le hóa"=I don't believe he's slowly [afterthought cleft] reading something about a boy going to the story
seaqtaq (2024-07-16T08:55:32.067Z): Similarly, in "Bu chı jí, ꝡá noaq nháo sá, ꝡä fa déo jéarıaq zûo pó báq noaı, ïgo bu le hóa, ïgo kuı hôa sá bụtuao", the second ïgo esssentially functions as gö in this case since there are only three neating levels

ım +2 `en` @uakci #i7_nS8iXF 2023-04-19T01:02:47.961Z
name verb: turns the following reduced relative clause into a verb: ▯ is named “[that clause]”.
uakci (2023-04-19T01:05:58.209Z): by reduced relative clause we mean the kind of stuff that appears inside of a determiner phrase – so **ım** extends to entire serials, adjectives (with or without overt **kị-**), and object incorporation, but not **jü** or **ꝡë** (which are CPᵣₑₗ-external, n*P-internal), so use those for attaching adjectives that should not be considered part of the name

ıq- +2 `en` @Laqme #xR7mJHGy0 2024-10-10T18:55:31.743Z
prefix: turn a "that"-verb into a "to"-verb
Laqme (2024-10-10T18:57:55.581Z): For example, **ịqdıe suaq nháo** means **dıe nháo, ꝡä suaq nháo**.
Laqme (2024-10-10T18:59:12.405Z): In general, **ịqV**(x, P) means V(x, ꝡä P(x)).
Laqme (2024-10-10T19:02:09.397Z): Another example: zaı "hopes that…" becomes ı̣qzaı "hopes to…" / "hopes that they…"
jiqci (2024-10-10T19:02:16.985Z): this is like Eberban's **zue**!

ıq'ıq ± `en` @uakci #0s40RFIHo 2022-10-16T02:19:47.598Z
▯ satisfies property ▯ [emphatic and/or not reducible like **ıq**].
uakci (2022-10-16T02:20:40.660Z): while instances of **ıq** may be replaced by the application of the property, **ıq'ıq** remains as it places emphasis on the proprietor, the property, their relation, and the state of property-having/ownership
uakci (2022-10-16T02:21:53.075Z): e.g.,**ỉq jí kâto ja** should be identical to **kảto jí** except for pragmatics, whereas **ỉq'ıq** would not, and translate as ‘i have cathood’ necessarily rather than ‘i am a cat’

ıshoı ± `en` @seaqtaq #ybRVTik0q 2022-08-18T08:02:33.939Z
 ▯, as a member of a group sharing a contextually significanty property (whether it be ideology, religion, ethnic group, sports team preference, etc.), becomes wary/apprehensive upon a perceived outsider of said group joining in ongoing derision/criticism commonly held by typical members of said group due to being in said group—oftentimes of the group itself, but not always—being discussed by the group, where the perceived outsider joins in on the derision for a wholly different reason, as they don't share the contextually significant property
seaqtaq (2022-08-18T08:02:39.789Z): e.g.:  Socialists when a right winger joins in on making fun of liberals  LGBT people when a social conservative enters the conversation on the commodification of LGBT activism and its subsequent detriment to the overall movement, where the conservative is simply annoyed by pride flags being shown "everywhere"  A few members of [Insert ethnic group here] having fun embracing stereotypes and throwing slurs  at one another being suddenly interrupted by a true racist not of the ethnic group expressing agreement with the stereotypes being satisfied and asking the members of the ethnic group to agree to [insert racist belief here]  A bunch of Finns poking fun at serious issues in their nation when a non-finn comes along and begins to unironically hate on finland with an air of superiority
seaqtaq (2024-07-11T22:14:06.005Z): zakaı

jeha +2 `en` @Hoemai #-MLQG4xTd 2022-08-06T19:55:26.689Z
▯ is* the case.
Hoemai (2022-08-06T19:56:04.696Z): This predicate expresses that its argument is true and that this disagrees with a proposition from the immediately preceding discourse (there should be one most salient proposition). Like German "doch" and French "si", but as a verb. If no argument is provided, it defaults to the negation of the most salient proposition.
Hoemai (2022-08-06T19:56:25.562Z): A: **Bủ chỏ súq jí** B: **Jẻha chô jí súq**. A: "You don't like me." B: "Yes, I do like you."
Hoemai (2022-08-06T19:56:38.161Z): A: **Bủ bỉaq dẻ jí** B: **Jẻha da**. A: "I'm not pretty enough." B: "Yes, (you are)."
robintown (2022-10-25T01:06:46.961Z): See also **aımu**

▯ is the same as ▯ except for ▯ (2)
fagri (2019-01-23T19:43:24.000Z): The third slot is type 2 and works the same way as it does in jeq.  You can also put multiple relations in the slot with roi.  All relevant relations not included are stated to be the same.
fagri (2019-01-31T02:12:40.000Z): (Key words: parallel, analogy, analagous, panra, heojeq)
fagri (2019-01-31T02:12:55.000Z): (Key words: analogous)

jıeqja ± `en` @uakci #Fgg0WYzeZ 2023-11-14T07:47:44.160Z
▯ brings ▯ (situation) to its edge/utmost.
uakci (2023-11-14T07:49:56.258Z): **taocıa jıeqja roq nháo jí** ‘they unwittingly got me to tear up’, implying that the ‘tearing up’ reached its peak and then presumably receded afterwards. this is an aspectual distinction (X happening vs. X peaking) that’s not so easy to express in english so take my word for it. cf. **jıeqla**

jıeqkıoqbıa ± `en` @uakci #xZ-4v7raK 2021-08-19T17:43:38.270Z
▯ is sick with the coronavirus.
uakci (2021-08-19T17:45:10.752Z): Latin ‘corona’ refers to a crown, specifically to its characteristic ring of pointed details that it has. a “coronavirus” is any virus which takes the shape of a sphere that is peppered with extremities

jıeqla ± `en` @uakci #fdbWgoU0K 2023-11-14T07:46:51.773Z
▯ (situation) peaks/climaxes / reaches its apex (in terms of extent/intensity).
uakci (2023-11-14T07:47:25.140Z): **kú pûcham nä jıeqla jaı jí** would mean more or less ‘my happiness peaked yesterday’
uakci (2023-11-14T07:51:21.919Z): this word expresses a rather nuanced aspectual distinction. when **nuokuaı jí** means ‘i was sleepy’, **jıeqla nuokuaı jí** could be translated unwieldily as ‘i got sleepier and sleepier until reaching a peak/extreme of sleepiness [and then it presumably got better. idk maybe i napped or maybe the urge abated a little]’

jımo ± `en` @uakci #xSl4cDNYo 2022-08-10T11:09:33.888Z
text quote: the mathematical/logical/symbolic formula designated by the sequence of symbols uttered in X expresses fact ▯.
uakci (2022-08-10T11:10:21.995Z): **jẻo jímo p → q → (p → q) teo da** “the formula ‘p → q → (p → q)’ holds”
uakci (2022-08-10T11:11:21.057Z): whether variables are bound or free in the quoted expression or what their domain is is up to context; in this sense, **jımo** does not return a unique ‘interpretation’ of the formula given, and :t2:/**ke** implicitly selects the contextually plausible one
uakci (2022-08-10T13:51:06.058Z): < **jıoq** + **mo**
uakci (2022-11-10T15:07:35.209Z): = **po mó … teo ga củaq**
uakci (2023-05-22T18:44:38.297Z): update to this word: let’s say **jımo … teo**₁ is not actually restricted to facts, such that it can point to (non-propositional) expressions, values such as addresses or phone numbers or serial numbers, etc.

pronoun: false 1st-person plural
lassc (2025-04-01T12:19:07.476Z): etym: **jína** + **aq**
lassc (2025-04-01T12:19:22.580Z): kw: royal we/us/our, "youtuber" we
lassc (2025-04-01T12:20:59.367Z): realistically only refers to the same referents as **jí**, but implies reference to **jína**
lassc (2025-04-01T12:21:08.289Z): cf. **zéoı**
lassc (2025-04-01T12:23:06.857Z): to be clearer: it's still perfectly fine to refer to more people than are actually relevant to the statement involving them (even if its unclear), this is just a means of denoting a distinction in meaning

jıoq +1 `en` @official #iXy4o68cV 2019-06-26T12:55:48.106Z
predicate: ‘calculate’; ▯ calculates what satisfies property ▯.

jıoq +1 `en` @uakci #YFQwzEYEH 2021-11-06T21:00:00.390Z
▯ calculates ▯ [see notes].
uakci (2021-11-06T21:00:17.906Z): this is a reformulation of <@official jıoq> that avoids depending on properties as answer-givers. x₂ may be filled with a proposition or an indirect question
uakci (2021-11-06T21:00:57.132Z): if x₂ is a (non-interrogative) proposition, the verb means “to calculate that x₂ is the case”; “to come to the conclusion that x₂ is the case through calculation/reckoning”
uakci (2021-11-06T21:01:45.313Z): ex.: **jıoq jí pêu péı jo péı gu péı gu** – ‘I calculate that 2 + 2 = 4’
uakci (2021-11-06T21:02:27.755Z): this form may be used in a serial (**jıoq peu jí péı jo péı gu péı gu** = the same); moreover, you can say **jıoq peu jí** ‘I add’ (I calculate addition operations)
uakci (2021-11-06T21:03:00.201Z): if x₂ is a polar interrogative proposition (one with **ma**), this verb means “to verify if x₂ is the case”. x₂ is not asserted
uakci (2021-11-06T21:03:34.381Z): if x₂ is an interrogative proposition involving **tıo**, **co**, **hı**, this verb can be translated like the official definition – x₁ calculates what the answer to x₂ is

jıoq +1 `en` @fagri #IQzrU8uBm 2023-06-13T15:49:07.702Z
▯ calculates the answer to question ▯
fagri (2023-06-13T15:50:06.011Z): «Jıoq séoqtuedıupoq mä ruqshua râo jı́achaq» = "The meteorologists calculated whether it will rain tomorrow"
fagri (2023-06-13T15:51:29.901Z): «Jıoq nháo wä reu hı́ shı́ko gúko» = "They calculated the product of the first and second number"

jıq- ± `en` @uakci #FkNtiXb-C 2023-06-07T07:53:00.912Z
prefix: given a verb X expressing a denomination of date or time, form a new verb meaning “▯ is the X described by the following number-expressions, where the first number-expression word is the denomination of X and each following word is one denomination higher”
uakci (2023-06-07T07:55:35.608Z): < **jıoq**. examples: **jịqchaq 15 2 2021** = ‘the 15th [day] of the 2nd [month] of the 2021st [year]’, or 2021-02-15; **jịqmınu 31 13** = ‘the 31st [minute] of the 13th [month]’, or 13:31
uakci (2023-06-07T07:57:27.042Z): to clarify, these are pronounced like regular™ numbers (except that i assume you may omit **heı**, etc.), so the first example would be fully spelled out and pronounced as **jịqchaq shıfe gu gukoamgushı**
uakci (2023-06-07T08:28:41.211Z): i meant hour not month in that second example btw. also, these units may be mixed date–time, e.g., **jịqhora 23 27** ‘23:xx on the 27th’

uakci (2022-08-15T13:46:14.327Z): < **juoıtaq**
uakci (2022-08-15T13:57:06.002Z): hyponym of **ıq**. this word is to be applied to properties that are satisfied mostly through identification “from within”/arising from internal/personal experiences rather than externally assigned titles/labels

kalo ± `en` @jiqci #tYmiprJP2 2023-06-22T19:57:39.922Z
▯ is a calorie/kilocalorie.
jiqci (2023-06-22T20:01:14.321Z): there were historically two calories, the large calorie being the amount of energy required to heat 1kg of water by 1 degree, and the small calorie being 1/1000th of that, i.e. heat required for 1-degree change of 1g of water. The term "calorie" nowadays refers to the large calorie, while "kilocalorie" means 1000 of the small calories, i.e. the two are equivalent.

kaqjeo ± `en` @fagri #ylRRH91wB 2019-01-09T06:40:02.000Z
▯ satisfies property ▯, which describes something about how it/they look
fagri (2019-01-09T06:41:52.000Z): For example, "Kảqjēo hó lî jảqjēq shẻaqsāo ja dó báq mủao da", she was as tall as a tree.
fagri (2019-01-09T06:42:45.000Z): On the other hand "Kảqjēo hó lî jải ja dó" is NOT true even if "Jải hó" is true, because "lî jải ja dó is not a property describing how dó looks
fagri (2019-01-09T06:44:02.000Z): This word is useful to form phrases like "I don't know what she looks like".  (Kảqsīu, "▯ looks like ▯" would not be appropriate, because that's a comparison between two concretes)
fagri (2019-01-09T06:45:01.000Z): Oh, and I just thought of "jêo hó hi káq", so consider that too before using this word; it might be better.
uakci (2023-07-28T10:50:12.391Z): (→ **kaq'ıq**)

Laqme (2019-04-20T22:00:49.000Z): Also "version" or "adaptation". e.g. kéokōpī Fảrāqsē = the "French version" of some work: the original wasn't (in) French, this one is, and otherwise (theme, plot, format etc.) the works are the same.

Laqme (2022-05-26T10:38:23.186Z): I like **hey** better these days
lassc (2023-10-18T13:36:03.869Z): remix, variation

keopıshuaq ± `en` @Laqme #gxlmG5g5_ 2019-04-20T22:04:13.000Z
▯ creates a quasi-copy of ▯ that satisfies ▯, unlike the original;  ▯ adapts ▯ into a version that distinguishes itself by satisfying ▯.

konıaq ± `en` @Laqme #R6OdrL6Fi 2019-02-08T14:23:24.000Z
▯ is year ▯/n.
Laqme (2019-02-08T14:27:23.000Z): In lengthier terms: “▯ is the year n, where n is the cardinality of something satisfying property ▯.” So «kónīaq gủbīqhēınēı» is “the year 2019 (of some implicit era or calendar)”.
Laqme (2019-02-08T14:32:26.000Z): In practice, this implicit era or calendar will often be the “Common Era” starting at 1 CE, but I didn't really want to encode this baggage in the predicate. I think something like #kogīqnīaq would be nice for years before the implicit epoch, say “year n BCE”.

ku'aı ± `en` @seaqtaq #Twooh8oMY 2020-07-03T01:30:24.725Z
'orientation'; ▯ʼs orientation in aspect/relevant to property ▯  is described by property ▯
seaqtaq (2020-07-03T01:34:25.288Z): Word form inspired by "kuaı". The second place relates to a scale and/or collection of beliefs or behaviors and the third place describes exactly what behaviors or beliefs the referent of the first place exhibits, or where they are on the scale
seaqtaq (2020-07-03T01:41:25.901Z): "Kủxāı súq lî củe ru cảq ja baq jủaocīao hı moq?"—"What is your political orientation" (Or "Please describe what properties best describe your beliefs/behaviors as relevant to ruling and managing societies")
seaqtaq (2020-07-03T01:42:28.536Z): This bisyllabic root is purposefully very broad and as such can be used to name sexual, gender, political, etc. orientation
salarua (2022-09-13T20:58:16.663Z): word form is no longer distinct from kuai

ku'aı ± `en` @seaqtaq #tEiknLi87 2020-07-03T02:02:56.766Z
 ▯ is ▯'s orientation in regard to property ▯
seaqtaq (2020-07-03T02:05:38.281Z): Word form inspired by "kuaı". The second place relates to a scale and/or collection of beliefs or behaviors and the third place describes exactly what behaviors or beliefs the referent of the first place exhibits, or where they are on the scale  "Kủxāı hı súq lî củe ra cảq ja baq jủaocīao moq?"—"What is your political orientation" (Or "Please describe what properties best describe your beliefs/behaviors as relevant to ruling and managing societies")  This bisyllabic root is purposefully very broad and as such can be used to name sexual, gender, political, etc. orientation

leam ± `en` @uakci #xRzOFde9x 2023-04-24T08:47:08.443Z
number component: lakh, 100,000 (for specifying large numbers in accordance with the Indian numbering system)
uakci (2023-04-24T08:49:55.061Z): **leam** is 10⁵. any further powers of 10^(5+2n) are rendered as compounds of **leam** with an appropriate multiplier: crore (10⁷) = **fueleam**, arab (10⁹) = **ꝡeamleam** or **heıbıqleam**, kharab (10¹¹) = **megaleam** or recursively **heıleamleam**, etc.
tonibrown (2025-02-26T05:50:44.309Z): keyword: hundred thousand

lı ± `en` @uakci #phXJYoHPd 2023-12-02T12:21:19.174Z
As a general rule, one satisfies, with ▯, relation ▯; [≈ **he** **ıqha**]
uakci (2023-12-02T12:23:14.838Z): **he** often goes with **há**, so understand **lı** as an abbreviation of this pattern: **he huaqcho há báq kırı** ‘one usually prefers cute things’ = **lı huaqcho báq kırı** ‘cute things are preferred’
uakci (2023-12-02T12:28:02.375Z): syntactic aside: since **lı** has a built-in **ha** Asp node, i’d like to treat **lı** as the masked spelled-out form of an Asp node above and a V node below, namely **he** and **ıqha**
uakci (2023-12-02T12:29:10.491Z): (in other words, some ✨automagical syntactic process✨ turns the continuous sequence **he ıqha** into **lı**, perhaps during Spell-Out, the syntactic phase infamous for having all kinds of magic shoved into it

uakci (2025-10-07T09:05:16.499Z): **lị́aru** ‘both this and that’; **lị́arubu** ‘the former but not the latter’

lîalu ± `en` @robintown #JTAQ_Zh6N 2024-11-19T04:37:16.792Z
adjunct head: forms subject-sharing adverbials (allomorph ◌̂)
robintown (2024-11-19T04:47:24.296Z): In official Toaq you will only ever see this word as its tonal allomorph ◌̂. However, a non-tonal representation is useful as it gives us a nicer 'identifier' for the morpheme and opens up the possibility of it existing marginally similar to **ló**.

lıam +3 `en` @Laqme #XFTygUdWy 2024-09-29T10:44:15.258Z
▯ is a sign/indication of ▯.
Laqme (2024-09-29T10:46:41.208Z): symptom, evidence
Laqme (2024-09-29T10:47:38.352Z): I'm splitting an accidental sense of **laı** out of that word so that that word can just mean "glyph, letter".
Laqme (2024-09-29T10:48:33.784Z): This makes for a nice adverb: **lîam, ꝡä ...** = indicating that / showing that ... is the case.
Laqme (2024-09-29T18:37:03.173Z): **Lıam, é ruı púao, ꝡä fịruqshua** = The clouds being gray is a sign that it's about to rain.
Laqme (2024-09-29T18:39:48.558Z): **Lıam, é geı jí báq gıaqchea, ꝡä shao sịakeoı jí** = Me wearing headphones is a sign that I want to not talk to anyone.

lıeı +3 `en` @Laqme #nfJuIXszk 2024-05-18T09:10:24.973Z
▯ follows / matches / obeys / goes along / is in accordance with ▯.
Laqme (2024-05-18T09:15:05.062Z): This is a lot like *tiao*, and almost equally generic, but the object sets a tone/example/lead/constraint and the subject follows or fulfills it
Laqme (2024-05-18T09:35:56.705Z): A path "follows" a river, proper behavior "follows" the rules, an improvised melody "follows" the chords, mountain ranges "follow" tectonic plates, data "follows" a pattern, files "follow" a file format, an artwork "follows" an aesthetic or movement, you "follow" your tango dance partner
seaqtaq (2024-11-14T22:42:57.791Z): Conform
lassc (2025-03-12T05:40:15.399Z): acquiescence

lıpoe ± `en` @fagri #fvr0hGlXw 2019-12-25T23:52:27.014Z
What satisfies property ▯ is independent of what satisfies property ▯
fagri (2019-12-25T23:53:07.622Z): In other words, there are no ordered pairs (A, B) that are forbidden from satisfying the properties (P1, P2), unless A is always forbidden from satisfying P1 or B is always forbidden from satisfying P2
fagri (2019-12-25T23:53:40.240Z): Another way of saying the same thing is that the ordered pairs (A, B) that can satisfy (P1, P2) are simply the cross product of the values A that can satisfy P1 and the values B that can satisfy P2
fagri (2019-12-25T23:54:27.804Z): This word only kind of came up in a real context and might turn out to be designed from too high an ivory tower to be useful

loao +1 `en` @fagri #irTpBtujm 2019-02-18T22:52:22.000Z
[PO] property ▯ is satisfied by [complement]
fagri (2019-02-18T22:54:04.000Z): A single-arg applicator in PO.  Example: "Lóao jí ga pảı" = "Lú pảı jí hóa na".
fagri (2019-02-18T22:54:55.000Z): This saves one syllable on moving from lu-hoa-na to loao-ga, and if this were given a CV or CVv root, which I don't necessarily recommend, it would save another syllable.
fagri (2019-02-18T22:55:05.000Z): See also the #goji series

loeq +1 `en` @uakci #-E6dKlMwd 2022-12-02T17:17:16.155Z
▯ cooks/is cooked.
uakci (2022-12-02T17:17:28.338Z): replaces **loy**, **lony**
uakci (2022-12-02T17:18:45.854Z): boils, boiled; cooks, cooked; fries, fried; steams, steamed; treats, treated; pickles, pickled; ferments, fermented; ages, aged; smokes, smoked; kneads, kneaded
uakci (2022-12-02T17:20:25.242Z): (not all of these glosses make sense as unaccusatives but including them for completeness
uakci (2022-12-02T17:23:39.688Z): bakes, baked; ovens, ovened; marinates, marinated; sautées, sautéed
uakci (2022-12-02T17:25:35.588Z): spoils, spoiled; rots, rotten; molds/moulds, moldy/molded/mouldy/moulded
uakci (2024-03-11T15:24:06.598Z): this is an unaccusative verb, meaning that **loeq kásı** means ‘the nuts cook/are cooking’ and not ‘the nuts cook themselves’ or ‘the nuts are cooked by somebody’ (although this could still be implied). use **tua loeq** for transitive ‘cook’, e.g., **tua loeq jí kásı** ‘i cook the nuts’. also, this word expresses the action of cooking – becoming cooked – and not the state of having been cooked (so possibly ready to eat) – for that, use **luı loeq**, or its abbreviated variant **loq'e**

▯ is LGBTQ+.
robintown (2023-11-07T17:38:41.709Z): Etymology: Compared to **leuq** this is a considerably more modern term, designed to read as 'LGTBQ' in Derani. Alternatively, a common folk etymology tells that it was formed from a reduced form of **leuq** + **túq**.

Laqme (2022-06-30T15:57:25.200Z): There isn't really a good English word for this, but it's something people in "hacker culture" tend to do all the time, and it's big among conlang communities as well.

meq- ± `en` @uakci #5lDBV3chi 2023-10-13T09:33:25.130Z
prefix: turn verb into focus prefix
uakci (2023-10-13T09:38:53.112Z): see **meq**, **kueu**. the mechanics of this word goes as follows: •if X is binary, then the focus prefix feeds the focused part of a proposition as the first argument and the ‘remainder’ expressed as a lambda as the second argument. for example, **cho jí mẹ́qsoq súq** transforms into **soq súq, lä cho jí já**. in this vein, **mẹ́q'ıq** corresponds to the no-op focus prefix. note that the original preposition is lifted, i.e., no longer asserted (in favor of the ancillary proposition whose predicate is X); •if X is unary, then the use of the focus prefix is equivalent to an adjoined clause with it replaced by **kú** – for example, **cho jí mẹ́qgıfaq súq** transforms into **cho jí súq; gıfaq, ꝡä cho jî kú súq**. note that this use is essentially similar to an eventive adverb (here, **gîfaq**), so like a focused/scoped adverbial if you will

meq +1 `en` @Ilmen #RSxfBglvT 2020-01-10T22:19:31.238Z
quantifier: the proposition in which this quantifier appears is treated as a property with a lambda slot placed exactly where this quantifier appears; the resulting property is then claimed to satisfy the first slot of the predicate introduced by this quantifier.
Ilmen (2020-01-10T22:21:45.283Z): ``mủıdūa meq nỏa ní`` = ``nỏa mûıdūa ja ní``.
Ilmen (2020-01-14T17:13:28.836Z): ``meq hảo`` is similar to ``hão`` but instead of delivering a proposition (lû) to the first slot of ``hao`` as is the case with the latter, it passes a property (lî) to it. Compare ``chỏq jí ní jẽaq dảqfāı`` —"I use this increasingly frequently"— with ``chỏq meq pủıjēaq ní`` —"increasingly many ones use this"—.
Ilmen (2020-01-14T17:13:41.081Z): What can be expressed as ``gủaı meq dùq póq`` under the alternative definition #46CV57Aje can be expressed as per this very definition as ``gủaı póq ru meq hỏpā dủq``, which is three syllables more. Hopefully the additional flexibility allowed by this one definition is a sufficient compensation.

mẹ́qjoq'ıq ± `en` @uakci #Rz5ut7I-m 2024-01-07T08:27:29.594Z
focus marker: primarily, predominantly, mainly, chiefly, overwhelmingly, as a majority (of cases / of concern)

mera +1 `en` @Laqme #Pl51IIkL7 2024-04-24T21:31:18.269Z

mı- +2 `en` @uakci #NAS9wtQdz 2023-06-03T11:54:46.879Z
prefix: turns the following verb X into a name marker that expects a word «Y» and turns it into the verb: ▯ is an X named «Y».
uakci (2023-06-03T11:55:32.184Z): example: **mịhıu Lue** ‘the river Yellow’
uakci (2023-06-03T11:57:24.191Z): the definition is a little silly and hard to follow so think of the word this way: it takes a verb and produces a specialized **mı**. so **mịhıu Lue** ‘to be a river named Yellow’ is a specialization of **mı Lue** ‘to be [something] named Yellow’

mı ± `en` @official #Dgwmfsoacq 2023-01-13T19:24:52.156Z

mı +1 `en` @uakci #ioiqJZ3A0 2023-06-03T12:41:09.283Z

mımoe ± `en` @uakci #wo56vtLG- 2022-06-20T08:02:39.524Z
onomatopoeic/mimetic quote: ▯ goes X (as in, displays behaviour or state of mind or feeling that “rattles” like X; not necessarily that they *say* X out loud).
uakci (2022-06-20T08:04:03.842Z): apt for the entire range of sound-symbolic vocabulary out there (from phonomime to phenomime to psychomime); can be used to borrow mimetic vocabulary from other languages on the spot; also intended to be used with interjections, as in **mımoe oro** ‘to be like ugh’ ≈ ‘to be (visibly) exasperated’
uakci (2022-06-20T08:07:10.326Z): this particle is in SHU and thus accepts one word of any form
uakci (2022-06-20T08:08:28.231Z): etymology: ‘mimetic’ + **moe**. i guess you could say it’s **mı** + **moe** too, same difference
uakci (2022-06-20T09:18:37.993Z): the word was at first intended to be able to capture and reuse interjections as verbs (as in, to be able to say things like “he ughed”), but on second thoughts it turned out to be much more versatile than that
uakci (2022-06-20T09:19:15.325Z): ≈ **aı shủ …**, **aı mỏ … teo** but more on-point and cuter
Snow (2023-05-24T12:00:54.758Z): keyword: onomatopoeia

fagri (2018-11-15T03:15:01.000Z): Note that this is NOT just another way of asserting the truth of a proposition.  "Tủrāq nâi da" is false because not every moment is this moment.  "Mỏjēo mó 'Nải da' teo da" is true because the sentence "Nải da" is always true when spoken.

molem +2 `en` @magnap #8HICOI_WT 2024-09-26T19:07:46.566Z
▯D/c holds in their mind the possibilities-inherent-in-▯N/0 (declarative *or* interrogative clause); from Estonian "mõtlema"
magnap (2024-09-26T19:36:44.486Z): in a declarative clause there is only one possibility to hold in your mind, and so this means something akin to "believes"
magnap (2024-09-26T19:37:14.899Z): in an interrogative clause there are several possibilities to juggle in your mind, and so this means something akin to "wonders"
magnap (2024-09-26T20:22:50.807Z): believes, wonders, contemplates, ponders, thinks, thinks about

el (2022-05-20T05:41:05.999Z): useful in cases where the thing being quoted isn't a pure claim -- kuq₂ can be a t5-clause, for instance, but that doesn't help if you want to say "John said [something along the lines of] «jadı» [but perhaps in another language]"
el (2022-05-20T05:45:04.555Z): also useful when there's no actual *text*, like when used with **moıkuq**

mọsosorofofetaq -1 `en` @kazoo #UgtPyfFBm 2025-04-30T20:04:49.057Z
▯ is the White House.

mutu ± `en` @Ilmen #dA-4PYQgw 2021-11-03T22:40:34.336Z
binary quantifier: reversed universal; «hảo₁ mutu hảo₂» = «hảo₂ tu hảo₁».
fagri (2021-11-15T05:05:27.299Z): +1, this is very useful. I used to use «Raı tou baq hao» but I will now be using «Raı mutu hao», which is more correct
fagri (2021-11-15T05:05:57.757Z): tags: only, all
uakci (2022-02-27T09:02:49.307Z): +½; i’m concerned about the inflexibility of this word wrt to other members of SA – i like the idea of keeping the nuance between **tou baq hảo**, **tou sa hảo**, **tou tu hảo**, **tou tuq hảo**, etc.
robintown (2022-02-27T14:57:34.211Z): +1, tou baq hảo is questionable and not a great replacement for this word, which I find far more elegant
robintown (2025-01-15T17:43:06.179Z): haha I have totally reversed my opinion on this. I like tó báq/sá hao, whereas this looks more alien.

nạ́'ao +1 `en` @salarua #xNXVz1ZJR 2024-10-05T22:28:13.553Z
conjunction: except
salarua (2024-10-05T22:28:57.079Z): X nạ́'ao Y denotes that a statement would be true for X if it were true for Y; i.e. Y is an exception to the statement being true
salarua (2024-10-05T22:30:32.332Z): "Tı tú mea póqme jıbo nạ́'ao mí Moıra géqme da" = "Everyone in my group except Moira was at the meeting"
salarua (2024-10-05T22:31:39.538Z): Or more literally: "'Everyone in my group was at the meeting' would have been true if Moira had been at the meeting"

näꝡa ± `en` @Ilmen #Exo8377ZD 2024-02-22T20:16:59.388Z
particle: discourse-level frame-setting cleft — placed after a tense or modal expression, setting it as the domain in which the following sentences are evaluated as true, until the next occurrence of ⟪näꝡa⟫. May be used for introducing storytelling, in which case the following sentences are set to describe a context unrelated to the “here and now” of the speaker and addressees, describing instead events set in the past or in an imaginary universe.

no- ± `en` @uakci #qMYho2EIa 2022-12-21T21:15:35.678Z
prefix: [identity prefix]; X
uakci (2022-12-21T21:17:40.838Z): h/t @Laqme. intended to be used in situations where two bindings would otherwise clash – an extra **no-** at the front of one of those bindings distinguishes them nominally. e.g., **he ꝡä maı báq poq báq nọpoq shê ꝡä maı nópoq póq**, 'a person usually loves another person if the other person loves that person'. notice how **no-** translates to '(an)other' in this example

no ± `en` @official #DkEajFOlUS 2019-05-05T22:26:54.499Z

noa- ± `en` @seaqtaq #HACw0V0US 2024-10-18T16:11:52.769Z
prefix: turns verb X into ▯ finds it hard/difficult to X

nubo +1 `en` @uakci #Fi0WykEbN 2019-04-12T07:39:26.000Z
▯ is such as ▯; ▯ satisfies the propertie(s) which ▯ is characterised (characterized) to satisfy.
uakci (2019-04-12T07:41:40.000Z): Explanation: we take the x2 and look at what properties it’s typically associated with; then, we assert that x1 has them. For example: **nủbō ní bủajīo báq lỏe**, if flames are known to be hot, bright, and burning, would assert that that building is hot, bright, and burning.

takoda (2024-10-28T02:42:57.612Z): Simplified version of official **nue** without the audience slot. You can use **côm**.
takoda (2024-10-28T02:49:03.642Z): This does not imply the subject actually intends to do it. Ill-intentioned promises, fake promises, and empty threats are also covered by this word.

num +3 `en` @Laqme #JMGiPbFSd 2025-05-11T17:54:05.295Z
▯ involves ▯.
Laqme (2025-05-11T17:54:50.399Z): Also: features / uses / takes / is powered by / runs on / depends on.
Laqme (2025-05-11T18:00:42.831Z): A bit like **choq** without agency, or like **chıa** without the vibe of obligation. The intent is for **nûm** to be a quite generically applicable preposition ("involving").
Laqme (2025-05-11T18:06:17.284Z): Math *involves* numbers, Toaq *features* serial verbs, this recipe *uses* soy sauce and a wok, love *takes* courage, computers *run on* electricity, and (crucially) events *involve* all their participants.
Laqme (2025-05-11T18:09:21.623Z): Probably about as generic as **bo**.

numero ± `en` @xorxes #I3Lozgsc_ 2021-08-27T16:47:00.763Z
▯is/are a number of thing(s) satisfying property▯.
xorxes (2021-08-27T16:51:18.896Z): **Numērō shamū sa saq shamū da.** 'Three apples are a number of apples'
xorxes (2021-08-27T16:53:00.143Z): **Numērō baq saq da.** 'Three is (are) a number.'
xorxes (2021-08-27T20:34:59.632Z): **Ma numērō shamū sa gu ko saq paq shamū moq** 'Are two thirds of an apple a number of apples?'
xorxes (2021-08-27T20:50:40.436Z): **Ma numērō shamū sa coq shamū moq?** 'Are zero apples a number of apples?'

nhu- ± `en` @Neaqbua #hYS_LAmyo 2024-10-02T01:23:30.001Z
prefix: Names or refers to a variable like **nha-**, but otherwise behaves like the verb on its own, including variable binding.
Neaqbua (2024-10-02T01:23:42.113Z): 	For example, when you say ‹nhú-kune› for the first time (or ‹**nhúaı-**kune›), it binds ‹kúne›, ‹hó›, and ‹nhú-kune›. Then, saying ‹nhú-kune› will bring up the original referent, which again binds ‹kúne› and ‹hó›.
Neaqbua (2024-10-02T01:24:02.080Z): 	Intuitively, ‹nhú-kune› is read as "a dog that will remain relevant for a while" or "that dog from before."
Neaqbua (2024-10-02T01:24:13.853Z): 	‹nhu-X› can only be rebound by ‹**nhuaı-**X›. For clarity in long texts, you can introduce new ‹nhu-X› bindings always with ‹**nhuaı**-X›.
Neaqbua (2024-10-02T01:24:23.609Z): 	In contrast to **nha-**, the verb is not arbitrary: ‹nhú-raımı›, like ‹ráımı›, is restricted by the "raımı(_)" predicate.

nhu ± `en` @official #lsyM1JdP5P 2021-09-29T13:08:55.115Z
sentence connector: ‘anyway’; return to old topic

nhuaı- ± `en` @Neaqbua #S_5mEGPtU 2024-10-02T01:24:48.734Z
prefix: Like **nhu-**, but always names a new variable, overriding previous ‹nhu-X› bindings.
Neaqbua (2024-10-02T01:25:00.465Z): 	Introduces something relevant in the current context without worrying about previous bindings to the same word. See **nhu-**.
Neaqbua (2024-10-02T01:25:14.178Z): 	Intuitively, ‹nhúaı-kune› is read as "a dog that will remain relevant for a while."

nhuq'ao ± `en` @uakci #XgJn3l2hI 2023-06-04T15:36:07.369Z
▯ acts as a proxy/lackey/intermediary of ▯; ▯ does something for ▯ so they don’t have to do it themselves.
uakci (2023-06-04T15:36:18.016Z): use as a subject-sharing adverbial
uakci (2023-06-04T15:58:43.926Z): this is to specialize **nhuq** when it’s not really meant as a benefactive but as part of a separate frame (one of replacement/delegation). so **dıeq jí júo nhûq súq nha** ‘i’ll send the letter in your favor’ could be saying ‘i’ll send the letter to you’ (though you should use **com** or similar here) whereas **dıeq jí júo nhûq'ao súq nha** ‘i’ll send the letter in lieu of you [doing it yourself]’

o- ± `en` @lassc #mWgwK4-Dk 2022-12-06T22:21:20.125Z
prefix: ideophone of X
lassc (2022-12-06T22:21:40.503Z): post-delta **- go**
lassc (2022-12-06T22:27:12.578Z): examples (as was last time): o-kune "bark", o-roq "sob", o-maı ":pleading_face: / :heart: / etc"
lassc (2022-12-06T22:35:49.595Z): ideophones themselves more resemble interjections or adjectival things than they are verbs (hence why one would use **roq** to mention the action)
lassc (2022-12-06T22:36:30.968Z): this also isn't a replacement fr things that are more onomatopoeic and would benefit symbolism wise from having their own Lexical Item

uakci (2022-10-02T21:49:19.190Z): examples of **ocha** that may not be **poq** or **req**: those who don't consider themselves people; those who may be simulated or automated (or feel this way about themselves); fantastical/fictional creatures (demons, pixies, genies, etc.); sentient-seeming mares or delusions

ôq +2 `en` @Laqme #70rCWf6zQ 2023-02-18T00:50:22.160Z
Adjunct head for direct-object-sharing adverbials
Laqme (2023-02-18T00:51:56.694Z): **Hıeq jí kíoq ôq nıe tíaı** "I throw the ball into the box"
fagri (2023-05-26T05:56:57.302Z): Should the adverbial have «sho» added for «ôq sho nıe»?
Laqme (2023-08-26T12:04:19.833Z): I feel more and more strongly that it should have that bit of resultative flavor baked in, otherwise you're just saying ôq sho all the time
Laqme (2023-08-26T12:05:00.848Z): To describes something that the object is already doing, you can probably just use an adjective or relative clause
