pa- +1 `en` @uakci #RunxMd75v 2024-03-07T12:59:16.933Z
prefix: pre-fill the subject of the marked matrix clause verb with **súq** and require **ba** illocution (which may then be omitted, as ∅)

pa -1 `en` @el #6GYakxr1u 2022-10-20T05:49:04.377Z
argument fronter: takes a single argument (not an adverbial) to its left, and the verbal complex to its right; inserts the left argument between the verb and the first argument on the right
el (2022-10-20T05:49:25.078Z): must appear *after* all **bı**s; cannot be nested
el (2022-10-20T05:55:45.395Z): gritty details: **pa** is a pronounced F head(!) that generates with a VP complement (like current FPs) but also with an empty specifier (unlike them); Spec,V is moved out and into Spec,F, leaving the V' node intact and unmoved
el (2022-10-20T05:56:15.503Z): note that this means that sentences like **jí pa gı da**, with a unary matrix verb, are ungrammatical
el (2022-10-20T06:01:17.186Z): **jí pa fả jéarıaq**: [SAP [CP [C Ø] [FP Ø_1 [F' [F pa] [VP [DP jí<1>] [V' [V fa] [DP [D t2] [V jeariaq]]]]]]] [SA Ø]]
el (2022-10-20T06:01:48.076Z): with the DP marked <1> moving up to the node marked _1
Hoemai (2022-10-20T10:35:13.304Z): Looks like this (slightly adjusted): https://dprebyl.github.io/syntree/#%5BSAP%20%5BCP%20%5BC%20%C3%98%5D%20%5BFP%20%5BDP_1%20j%C3%AD%5D%20%5BF'%20%5BF%20pa%5D%20%5BVP%20%5BDP%20t%3C1%3E%5D%20%5BV'%20%5BV%20fa%5D%20%5BDP%20%5BD%20t2%5D%20%5BV%20jeariaq%5D%5D%5D%5D%5D%5D%5D%20%5BSA%20%C3%98%5D%5D

pá +2 `en` @Laqme #f_T-L2FKt 2022-08-17T06:13:42.365Z
illocution marker: imperative with elided súq subject
Laqme (2022-08-17T06:16:22.085Z): for example **Kaqsı jí pá!** = "look at me!". the subject DP had moved into SA, leaving a trace that makes the sentence "VO"
Laqme (2022-08-17T06:16:43.845Z): I just think súq...bâ imperatives aren't very snappy

peı- ± `en` @seaqtaq #WqdlJZD8- 2024-10-18T15:55:56.813Z
prefix: 'antimiddle voice': promotes subject in saliency, disallows referencing the object through even oblique semantic role marking
seaqtaq (2024-10-18T16:22:02.417Z): Tag: voice operator; "Pẹıchuq mí Joq mí Joq" == "John, he is eating". The english translation is deliberately stilted to emphasize the saliency promotion of the subject. One would be mistaken to attempt to add obliquely via thematic role marking the object of john's eating

zearen (2024-10-10T16:36:39.411Z): Yes, in most cases, as long as it has a long, thinner cylindrical handle, and a fine, smaller brush.  When I conceptualized this, I assumed it would be a conical brush, but a fan or an angle brush would probably also be piqso if they're meant for fine detail.  What a piqso is not is a paintbrush meant for, e.g. painting a house.

ponahuı +1 `en` @Laqme #HGMZ2shay 2025-05-07T11:14:29.985Z
▯ is an undesirable/inappropriate Toki-Pona-ism.
Laqme (2025-05-07T11:17:23.394Z): This is like **ıqlıhuı** (malgli) but for Toki Pona. It probably mostly describes the kind of "over-analysis" or "oversimplification" that arises as a result of a small lexicon (forcing speakers to speak in Toki Pona-like ways), or just as a result of conlangers sometimes thinking every conlang is like Toki Pona.
Laqme (2025-05-07T11:21:58.351Z): For example: I'd say my old word **kaınao** for "ink" is ponahuı, and **puım** is better.

pume +1 `en` @uakci #IwasyS0ML 2024-02-06T17:34:46.707Z
▯ is a/the past; ▯ is a/the sum of bygone*/historical* events.
uakci (2024-02-06T17:35:00.492Z): * does not imply ‘remote’ or some manner of emotional attachment or detachment
uakci (2024-02-06T17:38:59.182Z): this word is intended to be semantically similar to **me bâq pu**, ‘a bunch of events’. depending on the context, it may refer to the grand total of all that’s ever happen, or perhaps *my*/*your* past, and so on. it can be used in phrases such as ‘this relationship belongs [= **mem**] to the past’

rara +4 `en` @Laqme #-W0QS1OdY 2019-01-25T18:22:57.000Z
▯ is the case, or something.
Ilmen (2019-01-25T18:31:27.000Z): See also #sıujēo and #lısīu.
Laqme (2019-01-25T22:46:30.000Z): Some context: I wanted something fun and slangy-sounding and easy to say, and more {ie'o}-like and {sa'enai}-like than literally “similar to / approximate to having such-and-such-property”.  You can throw it anywhere as an adverbial interjection («rãrā») and it also works well in serials («rárā chủe»). This is apriori-ish, but duplicating the word for “or” seemed fitting, because that’s what a few languages I speak do, at least.
uakci (2019-01-25T22:48:03.000Z): +1
Hoemai (2019-01-30T16:15:00.000Z): +1
fagri (2019-12-19T03:37:40.628Z): +1

jeo dóshı sa lú sıu hóa dógu da

rıoq ± `en` @official #Sv2rMAqthm 2019-05-05T22:27:16.715Z
predicate: ‘type’; ▯ is a type/kind of ▯
fagri (2019-11-30T02:51:42.617Z): Should this be used with two (1) types? As with "Rỉoq lî kảtō na lî nỉaı da"? In this version, it would essentially be saying that the first property is a "subset" of the second one.
fagri (2019-11-30T02:53:55.766Z): The Toaq version would be: "Mẻa lú jẻo hóa ráı[1] na lú jẻo hóa ráı[2]"
uakci (2022-06-05T07:58:26.137Z): this word is perhaps best understood as a kind predicate (now that we have kinds, it’s only natural!), so e.g., **rỉoq baq kủochaı baq chảı** for ‘black tea is a kind of tea’. for properties, you may use **lıca**. for concretes, you may use **mea**
uakci (2022-11-01T17:26:41.898Z): perhaps more interestingly we could regard this predicate as being an implication operator over kinds: ∀X. lo(x₁)(X) → lo(x₂)(X). see **lo**

rıꝡeq +1 `en` @uakci #EXB23QKLR 2024-02-15T17:58:06.159Z
▯ is a ▯ of type ▯; ▯ is an instance of kind ▯, specifically the ▯ subkind of it.
uakci (2024-02-15T17:58:56.097Z): think of this word as a gluing-together of **eq** and **rıoq**: the first two slots are coupled with **eq** and the last two are coupled with **rıoq**
uakci (2024-02-15T17:59:46.626Z): **rıꝡeq ní báq rua hí?** ‘what type of flower is this?’ is to be understood as **eq ní hí rıoq bâq rua?**
uakci (2024-02-15T18:00:48.092Z): if the indirect object is omitted, we get the more elliptical ‘what type [of flower] is this flower?’: **rıꝡeq ní rua hí?**, which is equivalent to **eq ní rua hí rıoq?**

▯ is a determiner/quantifier applying sentential functor ▯ to (possibly restricted) outer property ▯.
uakci (2022-08-17T09:42:10.725Z): metalinguistic term. in a sentence like **hảo sa rủa jí** / [∃X. rua(X)] hao(X, jí), **shú sa** is x1, **jêo SA ja** is the x2 (the “functor”, more accurately a property of unary properties), and **hâo ja jí** is the x3
uakci (2022-08-17T09:42:40.021Z): **jêo sa ja**\*
uakci (2022-08-17T09:43:57.455Z): this word is probably not applicable to non-"true quantifiers" like **ja** or **hı**, who knows actually

uakci (2023-01-11T22:08:07.166Z): mostly to dispel the notion that **saja** could not refer to a **sıaja** despite the word form possibly suggesting otherwise
Ilmen (2023-01-11T23:06:33.111Z): Agreed.

sajabu ± `en` @Ilmen #VxMAeaNNF 2022-02-18T21:43:58.220Z
▯ is a nonpredicate (neither a predicate nor a proposition).

se- +1 `en` @uakci #skgFif30d 2023-10-25T11:06:18.762Z
prefix: turn verb X into verb: ▯ is in a state resulting from having X’d.
uakci (2023-10-25T11:07:25.347Z): this is slightly different from **luı** because it emphasizes the new state, this state being the end result of the action, rather than the action itself. it implies that some change was made and the subject is persisting that change
uakci (2023-10-25T11:08:17.221Z): you could also perhaps argue that a closed door *is* **luı rıasho** or **tẹrıatua** although that is petty and not up-to-speed with pragmatics and **mala** exists for that semantic space already anyway
uakci (2023-10-25T11:08:44.986Z): so perhaps this is reminiscent of the german zustandspassiv (‘is opened’ as opposed to ‘has opened’)

uakci (2020-02-09T23:24:58.029Z): also: ▯ is being ▯-ed (**te** without **luı**).
fagri (2020-06-27T16:10:35.346Z): uakci: how so?
uakci (2022-06-17T11:44:44.178Z): my note above is incorrect. **se**, turns out, is a semantic role predicate, not a syntactic role predicate like **mu** or **te**. for the definition suggested above just use **mu** (better yet, no passivizer at all)

sema +2 `en` @Laqme #_uCXd3G89 2025-03-20T14:43:13.826Z
▯ is/are an "intensional plural entity" (Int Pl e).
Laqme (2025-03-20T14:51:57.998Z): A **sema** is, under the hood, a function from worlds to plural constants. In kuna, this is the most basic denotation of an **aqmı**. For example, **túq gochıq** more or less denotes a **sema** that selects all cats from the world.
Laqme (2025-03-20T14:53:45.639Z): This concept is worthy of some primacy because the "environment of bound pronouns" can be thought of as a mapping from pronouns to **sema**-s.
Laqme (2025-03-20T14:54:27.149Z): Etymology: from their effective type signature "s → {e}" and the nominalizing suffix **ma**.

soq +6 `en` @uakci #8FtyCn9fR 2022-01-09T14:44:27.675Z
▯ satisfies property ▯ the most.
uakci (2022-01-09T14:45:47.458Z): this definition works flawlessly despite serial right-branching – e.g., **soq hủı pỏq** ‘the worst person’, **nı sỏq chủı tỉsha nỉ** ‘the first two to arrive here’
uakci (2022-01-09T14:49:46.970Z): actually, »despite« isn’t even the right word here. the complement of a **soq** serial can be attributive or predicative. if it’s predicative (say, A B), then **soq** sees the property of satisfying A the most (while also being B); if attributive, we still get valid semantics for things like **nuı kảnı** ‘small rabbit’, since the **nuı**-est **kảnı** is also the **nuı**-est thing that is also a **kanı**
uakci (2022-01-09T14:51:14.748Z): in other words, since the extent of an adjectival serial A B is proportional to the extent of A and not A × B (barring situations where B is flat-out false), **soq** will look at the correct »part« of the serial
uakci (2022-01-09T14:53:06.459Z): yet another way to look at it: in an adjectival serial such as A B, the A part is qualitative (how *much* something is A), whereas the B part is quantitative (*if* that thing is B *at all*). so rather than A × B we have something like the *truth value* of B times the *extent* of Aa
uakci (2022-01-09T14:53:29.079Z): if you agree with these postulates, you'll find this definition of **soq** unobjectionable
uakci (2022-01-09T19:37:09.791Z): CORRECTION: the example beginning in **nı sỏq chủı…** should read **gu sỏq chủı…** instead
el (2022-01-11T06:40:45.519Z): this definition also works very well with **meabı**, and that means **suı** can be defined similar to this

soq +3 `en` @fagri #yXBeLlHeW 2018-09-24T03:52:58.000Z
(fork of official) predicate: ▯, among ▯, is the ▯est;  ▯, among ▯, satisfies property ▯ the most
fagri (2018-09-24T03:53:41.000Z): This is great, because it behaves much more nicely in serial predicates.  +1 ;)
uakci (2018-09-24T04:59:19.000Z): +1!
Laqme (2019-02-12T19:34:48.000Z): +1 ♥
Ilmen (2025-10-31T09:58:40.938Z): officialized: yes

soq ± `en` @official #l9_PLTIBK 2022-07-19T18:30:54.087Z
predicate: ‘most’; ▯, among ▯, satisfies property ▯ the most.

soq +1 `en` @TheAndSys #XSeHcc5lt 2025-10-06T00:59:08.518Z
predicatizer: turns property into "the thing that satisfies [property] the most"
TheAndSys (2025-10-06T01:01:34.181Z): "ma zao súq sóq he juoq sı súq já?" -> "do you know what you should pay the most attention to?"
TheAndSys (2025-10-06T01:02:41.781Z): Can be achieved with typical soq + object incorporation but that whole thing is kind of lengthy and a bit of a mess since koitieq seems fine with underfilling even in sentences

soq ± `toa` @Ilmen #JP651xyO5 2020-01-30T15:03:34.089Z

sóq +1 `en` @uakci #1cKmcwq_t 2023-01-21T00:12:27.089Z
focus particle: the most
uakci (2023-01-21T00:15:48.288Z): extending hoemaı's analysis of english focus adverbs such as 'only' and 'even', which actually pair with sentence-level stress-based focus, we can see that 'the most' works similarly: '*I* like apples the most' (more than other people) vs. 'I like *apples* the most' (more than I do other fruit/food). **soq** used to be really inconvenient in convoluted situations and usually required a confusing **lu** clause to work at all, whereas this approach should feel much more natural
uakci (2023-01-21T00:16:13.257Z): see also 'prior work': **sojı** (which is a RU)
uakci (2023-01-21T00:17:11.473Z): related grammatical discussion (esp. the 'association with focus' part) https://toaq.net/refgram/syntax/#focusing_adverbs
robintown (2023-11-06T22:08:26.253Z): this is maybe a good translation for 'especially'

⚠ sou ± `en` @Machy #U6SM_6jVM 2022-02-07T21:16:37.838Z
non-assertive illocution
Machy (2022-02-07T21:17:09.479Z): credit: el
Machy (2022-02-07T21:17:32.554Z): "pragmatic function: introduce a sentence into the discourse as a topic, suggestion, as a thought to entertain, as an indirect quote to go off of, as a joke to present, as a metaphor to lay out, etc. the listener is expected to understand the sentence but not take it itself as true (thus pointing towards some other, hidden illocutionary meaning being conveyed)" —uakci
Laqme (2022-02-15T23:13:45.762Z): In English, this corresponds to some uses of writing a sentence in quotation marks, as if attributing it to some hypothetical speaker.

shao +5 `en` @uakci #FcGl3tIP1 2023-09-04T14:01:20.475Z
▯ wants to satisfy property ▯.
uakci (2023-09-04T14:03:15.765Z): rationale: this is easily the least intuitive thing about toaq to learners. they have to be told to use **ıqshao** for this frame. meanwhile, ‘to want to X’ is a super super super common catenative/modal verb/inflection in most languages i’m familiar with, and our departure from this seems to benefit nobody in particular. for (c 0) frame i’d suggest **faqshao** or perhaps **shao gaı**
Laqme (2023-10-31T22:56:06.750Z): Hoemaı has defined **aojaı** which I like to interpret as a gentle statement of support for this definition :)  +1
lassc (2025-03-20T09:07:54.094Z): wish, desire

uakci (2021-08-23T22:51:33.543Z): an aspectual predicate more stringent than **he** in that it asserts an essential, defining property of the kinds contained within it – in other words, while **he … baq X** may hold for a fraction of all X’s arbitrarily close to 1, **shehē … baq X** makes a statement about *all* X.

taıpoı ± `en` @fagri #iKXEdSFlh 2021-11-11T20:01:43.190Z

fagri (2021-11-11T20:01:46.016Z): «taı goı» usually means the wrong thing because it only implies that you succeeded in giving someone treatment, not that the treatment was effective and cured them. «taıpoı» looks inside the «goı», understands that events of «goı» are attempts at «tua rıu roe» and says that that attempt succeeded (e.g., the patient was cured)

tajı +1 `en` @fagri #BeCyXyc-f 2019-01-31T01:59:00.000Z

fagri (2019-01-31T01:59:51.000Z): I.e. "Making frequent backups is a way to prevent significant loss of data"

fagri (2019-01-31T02:02:19.000Z): (Although depending on the nuance of that word, this word might have a stronger implication that the method *works*)

teasaora +1 `en` @Hoemai #6rGZWL3HV 2019-04-01T22:58:36.000Z
▯ is a member of the superorder Dinosauria (the true dinosaurs).
Hoemai (2019-04-01T23:09:13.000Z): "Dinosaur" is from Ancient Greek δεινός (“terrible, fearful”) + σαῦρος (“lizard”), which is an alternative form of σαύρᾱ. δεινός (from PIE *dwey- (“fear”)) sounds like and is close in meaning to **tea**, while **saorā** sounds like σαύρᾱ but also happens to includes **sao**, which means "large", which is very fitting for dinosaurs. This compound is thus a lucky coincidence on two levels.

teıru ± `en` @uakci #3_P_uCQSg 2022-11-07T20:56:33.103Z
conjunction: ‘X, Y’; ‘and’ but conjugand order matters pragmatically
uakci (2022-11-07T20:58:32.173Z): lojban {ju'e}. seen in places like the ‘.’ in ‘i saw him. he was dead’, or the implicit conjunction in ‘the birds i saw which weren’t wounded’. to use **ru** in either case would be to discard the pragmatic sequencing of the operands, whose order of appearance is to match the speaker’s plan for how to sequence the information

▯ undergoes questioning/examining/interviewing with questions ▯; ▯ is tried/asked ▯.
uakci (2023-11-01T16:03:19.554Z): a very broad word, roughly: ▯ is in a situation where they are meant to share information by answering questions; ▯ has questions coming at them [in some formalized way].
uakci (2023-11-01T16:07:56.484Z): more specifically, could refer to: being examined / taking an exam / pop quiz / trivia quiz; being surveyed/polled / handed a questionnaire; being interviewed (as an employee; on the radio); being tried (as in witch trials), trialed (in court); questioned (by the police), put into doubt (wallslammed and forced to confess); bearing solicited witness/testimony; being rapid-fired icebreakers on a first date; so on so forth
uakci (2023-11-01T17:34:23.271Z): interrogated, interrogation

tíu ± `en` @salarua #Z-80MUDxy 2023-03-04T21:54:11.791Z
conjunction: ‘therefore’; therefore, so, thus
salarua (2023-03-04T21:56:48.249Z): example: Duo koı jóaq tíu póqme da. "The leader, and therefore the crowd, marched on."
uakci (2023-03-04T21:58:45.907Z): X, and therefore, Y
salarua (2023-03-04T22:19:23.902Z): additional examples: Bu chıetao jí pó jóemıeq tíu buaq jí da. "I didn't study for the test, so I failed it." Chaq meo jîe Kánadagua tíu jíaq da. "It is a sad day for Canada, and therefore the world."

uakci (2021-10-18T17:34:11.581Z): each member of x₂ is associated with a separate “act”. this allows one to, for example, ask multiple questions at a time (or to multiple people): **tủkuaq jí ní cỉ pỏq lâ ja jỉ ja pỏq bı dủasue jí súq chûa hı póq da** ‘Each of those six people, I ask you what they’re called.’ **tủkuaq jí súq dủasue ja jỉ ja pỏq chûa hı póq da** ‘Each one of you, what is your name?’

tuom ± `en` @Laqme #LEApWT4cH 2023-02-09T02:24:12.746Z
tense: default tense
Laqme (2023-02-09T02:25:27.528Z): This tense word means the same thing as not saying a tense word. uakci says Hoemaı says this is a "vague definite (temporal) reference".
uakci (2023-02-09T08:14:55.797Z): exact quote from @Hoemai: Both T and Asp are always there. When T is not overt, it is like using **hó** without an antecedent. The referent of the pronoun (the time interval referred to by the tense) is left to context. The default Aspect is **tam** because I can't think of a better default.

tuq ± `ja` @Laqme #YR5BR-BNA 2021-10-04T19:22:28.552Z
限定詞：「全ての…」（全体記号、McKayでのΛ∃）
uakci (2021-10-04T19:39:04.220Z): この量化系(SA)助詞とは、補語の述語動詞句を『最多数の(複数論理的)一定値』(*maximal reference*)に変化するもの。
uakci (2021-10-04T19:50:50.826Z): それからこういうmaximal referenceが求まれない可能性がある訳である。例えば「**tuq shỉ rủa**」の「**shı rủa**『一輪の花である』」という述語動詞句は、「非分配法則的」（*nondistributive*)なものなので、「一輪だけで全ての花」のことが集めれることが阻止されてしまうのである。

tuq ± `tok` @el #WUyKKUWkQ 2022-07-10T07:37:56.295Z
«tuq X» li sama "X ale wan"

ꝡarı +4 `en` @salarua #7vd0ieAJw 2025-05-20T22:55:46.082Z
▯ defiles/desecrates/profanes/violates ▯
salarua (2025-05-20T22:56:08.489Z): i.e. to damage something considered special, sacred, or protected. Need not be something physical.
salarua (2025-05-21T05:11:58.273Z): Not to be used lightly. This word is not about any specific acts, but rather it's about their effects — an ẹꝡarı is purposeful, malicious, and difficult or impossible to recover from. An ẹꝡarı against an object would compromise its sanctity, purity, or other intangible quality, even if the damage is reversible (e.g. ruining someone's deeply sentimental keepsake, vandalizing a holy site with racist graffiti). An ẹꝡarı against a person would be something traumatizing (I shall not list examples).
mimiaoganhaqpy (2025-05-21T06:54:47.434Z): +1: Very interesting word.  I like it.
lassc (2025-05-21T11:55:23.517Z): very good

ꝡoı- ± `en` @uakci #MOBDaiPdO 2024-05-08T19:20:10.063Z
pseudo-adjective head (grammar resembling **kị-**): relates a noun form and a reduced relative clause into a full clause in the vein of **ꝡöı**
uakci (2024-05-08T19:20:59.689Z): see **ꝡöı**. **báq rua ꝡọıhe sala** → **ꝡä he sala báq rua**

ꝡöı ± `en` @uakci #xvhpKLLgw 2024-05-08T19:17:42.308Z
faux relative clause marker piecing a noun form and a subject-truncated clause together into a full clause
uakci (2024-05-08T19:19:19.069Z): this is mostly to be used as a repair strategy to turn a noun form into a predication involving that noun form in afterthought. for instance, **báq rua ꝡöı he sala râo ní cao** ≈ ‘flowers… unfolding in this season’ = **ꝡä he sala báq rua râo ní cao**
uakci (2024-05-08T19:24:00.431Z): a “subject-truncated clause” here is meant in the sense of **lá**, i.e., a CP with the subject slot prefilled

zoe +5 `en` @lassc #bO9nRl6aL 2022-11-28T04:52:23.986Z
illocution: attribution of assertion to other party ("it's been said...")
lassc (2022-11-28T05:06:59.986Z): "I am not asserting this myself, but I have experienced others asserting this"
lassc (2025-03-16T16:57:13.030Z): also called a reportative. has the nuance of being illocutionary instead of evidential, meaning that it doesn't talk about a source of information, merely redirecting the statement away from being represented by the speaker

zoı- ± `en` @seaqtaq #Bopd4YcnA 2024-10-18T15:58:47.265Z
prefix: 'antipassive': demotes greatly the saliency of an object as well as removes it from the structure of a verb. The former object may only be referenced through oblique semantic role marking
seaqtaq (2024-10-18T16:07:08.841Z): . Tag: voice operator; Zọıchuq mí Joq" == "John eats [something]". Object is only referenceable obliquely through choosing the appropriate semantic role marker. "Zọıchuq mí Joq têcha háq" == "John is eating, with what's being eaten being the food" (John is even more salient than he would be in an active relation)

fagri (2019-12-28T23:40:37.749Z): Eg "durations are characterized by their size" means that the concept of "duration" has only one degree of freedom (size), which in still other words means that no two durations can have the same size (and "if they did", then they would actually be same duration)
fagri (2019-12-28T23:41:57.025Z): To give another example, people are NOT characteriszed by their names: two people can have the same name yet be different people, so "chẻo hẻo mủ chủa túq pỏq" is FALSE

- dıq ± `en` @uakci #nkL7th0iy 2023-06-08T07:41:47.520Z
informal suffix: in parallel to a **- dı** word, forms a verb of an arbitrary frame describing the act inherent to the identity described by that word
uakci (2023-06-08T07:43:20.930Z): **jurıdı** ‘to be lesbian’ → **jurıdıq** ‘to be [being/acting] lesbian towards ▯’

dote po ké muq lıo ± `en` @salarua #4VwXkQlET 2025-03-17T02:21:51.936Z
idiom: ‘gift from the left hand’; a superficially altruistic act with a self-serving ulterior motive
salarua (2025-03-17T02:24:11.297Z): The advent of modern hygiene in Toaqgua has made "clean" and "dirty" hands unnecessary, but some cultural connotations remain. It is considered uncouth at best and offensive at worst to give or accept a gift with the left hand.

pseudo-suffix: used for deriving the verb most commonly associated with a given stem
Hoemai (2023-04-07T16:33:37.278Z): Possible examples include **gıela** "to embrace/hug", **laıla** "to spell", **noqsaıla** "to season"

laı bạ'aıpu ± `en` @fagri #X_CEGLW83 2023-01-06T07:16:39.537Z
▯ is a falling diphthong mark (from the Derani writing system)
fagri (2023-01-06T07:17:04.090Z): So named because «aıpu» is the word used to form «aı'aıpu», the Toaq word for the diphthong «aı»

laı bạho ± `en` @fagri #R1GBPbyYh 2023-01-06T07:15:24.155Z

Ꝡä tı súq ní, bï jaı jí. ± `en` @robintown #sL7_nzMNF 2023-10-29T21:00:15.314Z
I'm happy that you're here.
robintown (2023-10-30T00:16:31.940Z): Lynn and I had a discussion about this, where we concluded that neither **kûı** or **gêm** really make sense for this meaning. As adjuncts, both constructions imply that you are, on the whole, happy. But imagine a situation in which you're having a bad day, and a friend comes to comfort you: you might say "I'm happy that you're here" even if it wouldn't be genuine to say "I'm happy". We found a paper https://www.semanticsarchive.net/Archive/DIzYWZkM/clauses.doc which claims that the clausal constituent participates in the semantics by a "regarding" relation, which suggests that a topic is the appropriate construction in Toaq. And there's similar evidence in Japanese to support this.

⚠ buy ± `en` @uakci #_R9G59Rg- 2021-08-26T14:17:10.991Z
▯ absolutely cannot occur; ▯ absolutely cannot satisfy property ▯ under any relevant circumstance.
uakci (2021-08-26T14:18:40.644Z): intended as a stronger, more consequential variant of **bu** to be used when translating words such as ‘blind’ or ‘deaf’ or ‘nogood’, where not only do we wish to negate one’s ability to do X, we also wish to stress that this inability/disability is not transient or able to be alleviated.
uakci (2021-08-26T14:26:39.510Z): as noted by @xorxes, this word can be replaced with **he bu daı** or **he bu deq** in most contexts. the use of this word in particular entails consequentiality and finality for the long-term

⚠ gusy ± `en` @Laqme #25fbVPs3D 2022-05-14T21:58:18.467Z

uakci (2022-05-14T22:10:50.052Z): two and no more
uakci (2022-11-30T20:47:07.865Z): note: the way this word was originally defined in the original toaq, it instead meant “exactly two plural constants”. this definition fails spectacularly for distributive predicates

uakci (2022-11-30T20:49:04.085Z): (by "this definition" above i mean the original definition. the definition in this entry is fine)

uakci (2022-02-28T21:32:19.700Z): when made to precede a verb, this word turns an a-posteriori observation into an a-priori claim about the definition of said verb. this word is orthogonal to illocution (it can be used with any DA, with varying meaning) and can be used more than once in a sentence (in which case more than one word is defined simultaneously)
uakci (2022-02-28T21:33:20.035Z): this is a metalinguistic tool and likely of little use in regular conversation

⚠ say -1 `en` @uakci #IzaBjQ3qm 2021-08-23T22:57:51.257Z
quantifier: some X, if any
uakci (2021-08-23T22:59:32.008Z): **P say Q** is taken to mean: ∃x.Px ⇒ [∃x.Px] Qx. in other words, the claim is tautologically true if the quantification fails
uakci (2021-08-23T23:01:53.251Z): also known as existential quantification without existential import – that is to say, unlike **sa P**, **say P** doesn't presuppose that P is satisfiable (that an x such that Px exists to begin with)

⚠ - ly -1 `en` @Laqme #PGXSejuTK 2022-02-08T16:01:44.459Z
suffix for diminutives (a small/precious/cute version of a noun, or a brief/indulged-in/fun/casual version of a verb)
uakci (2022-02-08T16:32:32.350Z): this suffix is totally imported from the English ‘ly’, for ‘love you’. 🙃
Laqme (2025-05-11T17:34:56.619Z): this is in a lot of old words (when y was a vowel); these days there's **gẹ-**
